  • Nerve to subclavius (C5, C6)- It supplies the small subclavius muscles.

questions.text: Which class of receptors trigger release of calcium from the endoplasmic reticulum?
questions.solution:
• After ligand binding, the G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) associates with an intracellular GTP-binding protein (G protein) that contains GDP. G-protein interaction with a GPCR-ligand complex results in activation through the exchange of GDP for GTP. Subsequent GPCR-mediated signaling pathways include the generation of cAMP and inositol-1,4,5-triphosphate (IP3), with the latter triggering release of calcium from the ER.

Option A: Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are integral membrane proteins (e.g., receptors for insulin, epidermal growth factor, and platelet-derived growth factor).

Option B: Lipid-soluble ligands can diffuse into cells where they interact with intracellular proteins to form a receptor-ligand complex that directly binds to nuclear DNA; the results can be either activation or repression of gene transcription.

Option C: Ligand binding to Notch receptors leads to proteolytic cleavage of the receptor and subsequent nuclear translocation of the cytoplasmic piece (intracellular Notch) to form a transcription complex.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 19

questions.text: A patient had a complaint of discharge from his penis for the last 5 days. Sample was taken and sent to the lab. On gram stain a lot of gram-negative bacilli were found. On culture small translucent colourless colonies were grown which were oxidase positive. What could be the most probable organism?
questions.solution:
Clinical features described in question, gram negative diplococci suggest Neisseria gonorrhoeae organism. Culture characteristics also suggest Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

In male there is discharge from penis, in females discharge from vagina is seen.

  • Moraxella catarrhalis: This organism causes sinus infection, nose infection, patient present with running nose of allergic life symptoms. So, it is wrong option
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa: This organism can cause infection ranging from skin inf, pneumonia, hospital acquired infection. But they are not gram-negative diplococci.
  • Acinetobacter actinatus: This organism causes a range of infections like skin inf, pneumonia, hospital acquired infection. But they are not gram-negative cocci.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 227.

questions.text:
A Patient Presented with Paraparesis, Paresthesia, Optic Neuritis, Dysarthria, Dysphagia which was Worsening with The Hot Baths or Increased Temperature Exposure. Probable Diagnosis was made as Multiple sclerosis. Find the false Statements Regarding this Condition?
1. It is Not an Autoimmune Disease.
2. It affects the Neuronal Membranes Conduction.
3. CT Scan is the Investigation of Choice.
4. Only Symptomatic Treatment is possible.
5. It is Nerve Conduction Disorder.
questions.solution:
• Defects in myelin can have major adverse neurologic consequences. One example is MS, an autoimmune disease that affects over 3 million people worldwide, usually striking between the ages of 20 and 50 and affecting women about twice as often as men. The causes of MS include both genetic and environmental factors.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice.
  • It is an autoimmune disorder.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page no 227-240

questions.text: The test to know the presence of air in the stomach and intestine in autopsy on new born is known as
questions.solution:
Stomach-bowel test (Breslau's second life test):

  • This is a corroborative test to Breslau's first life test/hydrostatic test.
  • It is based on the principle that when respiration is established, there is a probability that air is swallowed and may pass into the stomach and small intestine.
  • It is performed by placing double ligatures at each end of the stomach and at different parts of the small intestine.
  • The various parts are tested for floatation, and if positive results are shown, they are punctured under water, then the contained may be seen to escape to the surface.
  • If no escape, the test is negative

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 412

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for age-related macular degeneration?
questions.solution:
Low body mass index is not a risk factor for age-related macular degeneration, which is a degenerative disease of the retina that causes progressive loss of central vision. The other three options are known risk factors for the disease.

Reference: Kanski clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 572

questions.text: Inverted papilloma arises from?
questions.solution:
Inverted papilloma is a benign, epithelial neoplasm originating from the Schneiderian membrane of the nose and paranasal sinuses. It usually arises from the lateral nasal wall, in the middle meatus, often extending to the ethmoid and maxillary sinuses. In advanced cases, extension into all of the ipsilateral paranasal sinuses may occur, whereas intracranial growth and dura penetration are rare.

Reference: Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, 7th edition, Page no 1523

  • It is the substrate concentration at which the velocity reaches half of the maximum known as Vmax (similar to the efficacy of a drug).

choices.text: It is more shallow than male pelvis
The pelvic inlet is heart shaped
The greater sciatic notch is wider in females
The pelvic part of the chilotic line is longer than the sacral part

questions.text: All of the followings are true about female pelvis, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Difference between male and female pelvis:

  • The false pelvis is deep in male and shallow in females.
  • Pelvic inlet is heart-shaped in male due to jutting forward of sacral promontory. In females, it is transversely oval.
  • Pelvic cavity is smaller and deeper in male. It is a long segment of a short cone. In females, the pelvic cavity is roomier and shallower. It is a short segment of a long cone.
  • The pelvic outlet is smaller with ischial tuberosities turned inside in male. In females, the pelvic outlet is bigger with everted ischial tuberosities.
  • Sacrum is longer and narrow in male, while it is shorter and wider in females.
  • Subpubic angle is narrower, i.e. 50°-60°, in male. The angle is wider, i.e. 80°-85°, in females. This is the most important difference.
  • The greater sciatic notch is wider in females (75°) than in males (50°).
  • The acetabulum is large in males, and its diameter is approximately equal to the distance from its anterior margin to the pubic symphysis.
  • The chilotic line extends from the iliopubic eminence to the iliac crest. In females, the pelvic part of the chilotic line is longer than the sacral part.
  • The preauricular sulcus is more marked in females.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume- 2, 8th Edition, Page No 229

choices.text: Increase affinity of HbA for O2
Increase release of O2 to peripheral tissues

questions.text: Which of the following changes does not occur at high altitude?
questions.solution:
• Elevated BPG lowers the affinity of HbA for O2 (increases P50), which enhances the release of O2 at peripheral tissues.

Adaptation to High Altitude

  • Physiologic changes that accompany prolonged exposure to high altitude include increases in the number of erythrocytes, the concentration of hemoglobin within them, and the synthesis of BPG. Elevated BPG lowers the affinity of HbA for O2 (increases P50), which enhances the release of O2 at peripheral tissues.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, page no 57

questions.text: Necroptosis is characterized by all except?
questions.solution:
• Morphologically, and to some extent biochemically, necroptosis resembles necrosis, as both are characterised by loss of ATP, swelling of the cell and organelles, generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), release of lysosomal enzymes, and ultimately rupture of the plasma membrane.
  • Mechanistically, it is triggered by signal transduction pathways that culminate in cell death, a feature similar to apoptosis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 47

questions.text: Streptococcus is a medically important bacteria, it causes a range of infections in human beings, some of them are fatal. Streptococcal toxic shock syndrome is due to the following virulence factor.
questions.solution:
Streptococcal toxic shock syndrome is associated with the production of pyrogenic exotoxin A (SPE A). In this syndrome patient suffers from sudden onset of shock, organ failure and frequently death.

  • M protein: This is structure of Streptococcus but has no role in development of streptococcal toxic shock syndrome
  • Streptolysin O: This is structure of Streptococcus but has no role in development of streptococcal toxic shock syndrome
  • Carbohydrate cell wall: This is the structure of Streptococcus but has no role in development of streptococcal toxic shock syndrome.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, page no 213

questions.text:
Action Potential is a Self-Regenerative Process, Self-Propagated Process, Non Decremental Conduction with All or None Law. From the Given Below Events Arrange Them in Events Occurs in which phase of Action Potential?
A) Depolarisation-Na+ Channel Influx
B) Repolarisation-K+ Channel Efflux
C) After Depolarisation
D) Threshold
E) RMP
F) Upstroke
G) Overshoot
H) Spike
questions.solution:
RMP (Resting Membrane Potential) - E: This is the initial state of a neuron or cell at rest. The membrane is polarized, meaning there is a voltage difference across the cell membrane due to the unequal distribution of ions (more Na+ outside and more K+ inside). The neuron is not actively transmitting signals at this stage.

Threshold - D: When a stimulus is applied to the neuron, and the membrane potential reaches a certain critical level, known as the threshold, it triggers the initiation of an action potential.

Depolarization - Na+ Channel Influx (Upstroke) - A: Once the threshold is reached, voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels open, allowing sodium ions to rush into the cell. This rapid influx of sodium ions causes a sharp increase in membrane potential, which is the "upstroke" of the action potential.

Upstroke (Spike) - F: This corresponds to the rapid increase in membrane potential during the depolarization phase. It's often referred to as the "spike" or "rising phase" of the action potential.

Overshoot - G: During depolarization, the membrane potential can actually become more positive than the neuron's resting potential. This is called the "overshoot" and occurs because the sodium channels continue to stay open.

Spike - H: This is the phase where the action potential reaches its peak membrane potential, and it signifies the peak of neuronal excitation.

Repolarization - K+ Channel Efflux - B: After reaching the peak, voltage-gated potassium (K+) channels open, allowing potassium ions to leave the cell. This causes the membrane potential to return to a more negative value, which is called repolarization.

After Depolarization - C: After repolarization, the cell may experience a brief period where the membrane potential is even more negative than the resting potential before returning to its resting state. This is often referred to as the "after-depolarization" phase.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition, Page no 85-96

questions.text: Ant bite marks can be confused with -

questions.text: Which of the following is a common feature of both keratoconus and pellucid marginal degeneration?
questions.solution:
• Both keratoconus and pellucid marginal degeneration are corneal disorders that are characterized by corneal thinning.
  • Keratoconus is a progressive disorder that causes a conical bulging of the cornea, while pellucid marginal degeneration causes a localized thinning of the inferior cornea.
  • Corneal scarring, oedema, and ulceration are not typically seen in either of these conditions.

Reference: Kanski clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 248,250

questions.text: A 55 years old patient with a history of myocardial infarction was on aspirin for 3 years and now he is presented to medicine opd with occult blood in his stool. Inhibition of which of the following by aspirin would best explain this adverse event?
questions.solution:
• Aspirin, even in small doses, irreversibly inhibits TXA2 synthesis by platelets. Thus, it interferes with platelet aggregation and bleeding time is prolonged to nearly twice the normal value.
  • Long-term intake of large doses decreases synthesis of clotting factors in the liver and predisposes to bleeding. This can be prevented by prophylactic vit K therapy.
  • Aspirin particles coming in contact with gastric mucosa promote local back diffusion of acid. This causes focal necrosis of mucosal cells and capillaries → acute ulcers, erosive gastritis, congestion and microscopic haemorrhages. The occult blood loss in stools is increased by even a single tablet of aspirin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 213

choices.text: Nitrogen of urea is formed from ammonia and Aspartate
Rate limiting enzyme is Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase-I
Fumarate is a byproduct of urea cycle

questions.text: All are true regarding urea cycle except:
questions.solution:
• Nitrogen of urea is contributed by Ammonia and Aspartate.
  • Rate limiting step is Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase-I
  • Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I, the rate-limiting enzyme of the urea cycle, is active only in the presence of N-acetylglutamate, an allosteric activator that enhances the affinity of the synthesis for ATP. Synthesis of 1 mol of carbamoyl phosphate requires 2 mol of ATP
  • Fumarate is a byproduct of the urea cycle.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, page no 292,293

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does not cause Granulomatous inflammation?
questions.solution:
Ulcerative colitis is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that primarily affects the colon and rectum. Unlike Crohn's disease, which can show non-caseating granulomas, ulcerative colitis typically does not present with granulomatous inflammation. Instead, it is characterized by diffuse inflammation and ulceration of the colonic mucosa.

Other options:

(A) Sarcoidosis: Systemic inflammatory disease with multi-organ involvement and granulomatous inflammation in lungs, lymph nodes, skin, eyes & other organs.

(B) Cat-scratch disease: Caused by Bartonella henselae bacterium, it leads to swollen lymph nodes with possible granulomatous inflammation.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 101

questions.text: Autoinfection is seen with -
questions.solution:
Autoinfection

  • Autoinfection is the infection of a primary host with a parasite, particularly helminths, in such a way that the complete life cycle of the parasite happens in a single organism, without the involvement of another host.
  • Therefore, the primary host is at the same time the secondary host of the parasite.


Remember

Worms which do not multiply in host

- A. duodenale

- Enterobius vermicularis

- W. bancrofti

Worms that crawl out

-Enterobius vermicularis

- T. saginata

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology 8th edition, Page no 120, 190, 191

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important excitotoxic neurotransmitter in the brain?
questions.solution:
Glutamate is usually cleared from the brain's extracellular fluid by Na+ dependent uptake systems in neurons and glia, keeping only micromolar levels of the chemical in the extracellular fluid despite millimolar levels inside neurons. However, excessive levels of glutamate occur in response to ischemia, anoxia, hypoglycaemia, or trauma. Glutamate and some of its synthetic agonists are unique in that when they act on neuronal cell bodies, they can produce so much Ca2+ influx that the neurons die. This is the reason why microinjection of these excitotoxins is used in research to produce discrete lesions that destroy neuronal cell bodies without affecting neighbouring axons.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page no 610

questions.text: An Exploratory laparotomy was performed by a resident surgeon and at its conclusion, the surgeon was not informed about the swab count. Two months later, a further operation was done and a swab was found under the liver. The patient died later. The father of the deceased sued the surgeon for damages. The surgeon would be held negligent under the grounds of which doctrine?
questions.solution:
Res Ipsa Loquitur which translates to 'the thing or fact speaks for itself'. Not asking for a swab count after surgery is gross negligence. The patient need not prove negligence in such cases, he/she merely needs to state the facts.

Conditions to be satisfied for Res Ipsa Loquitur:

(1) that in the absence of negligence the injury would not have occurred

(2) that the doctor had exclusive control over the injury producing treatment

(3) that the patient was not guilty of contributory negligence

Examples :

  • Operating on the wrong part.
  • Prescribing overdose of poisonous medications.
  • Blood transfusion misadventure.

Option A: Novus Actus Interveniens: A person is responsible not only for his actions, but also for the logical consequences of those actions.

Option B: Medical Maloccurrence: An accident occurring even after taking reasonable precautions. Example: Damage to RLN during thyroidectomy.

Option D: Contributory negligence: When the patient or his attendant has also contributed to the negligent act.

References: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 39, 45, 38, 46, 47

questions.text: What is the best management for phacolytic glaucoma?
questions.solution:
• In phacolytic glaucoma, the cataract needs to be removed with or without intraocular lens implant insertion. Glaucoma surgery is usually not required and may cause hypotony. Topical corticosteroids are of little benefit in phacolytic glaucoma, but may be employed after the cataract surgery.

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 389

questions.text: Expansile and lytic lesions with soap bubble appearance in imaging are seen in?
questions.solution:
• Benign granuloma-like aggregates of giant cells in a fibrovascular stroma characterize this benign condition otherwise referred to as 'giant cell reparative granuloma' or 'giant cell reaction of bone'.
  • It was first described by Jaffe in 195351 in the jaws, though other craniofacial sites have been reported.
  • These lesions commonly occur in children and young adults and are benign despite the presence of mitoses which may cause the inexperienced pathologist difficulties. The giant cells do not contain multiple nuclei as in true giant cell tumours.
  • Bilateral symmetrical involvement of the jaws by giant cell granulomas is seen in cherubism, a rare inherited childhood condition. True giant cell tumours involving the craniofacial bones are quite rare especially in children and young adults.
  • To add to the confusion, the microscopic appearance of giant cell granulomas is indistinguishable from that of solid variant of aneurysmal bone cyst and must also be distinguished from the giant cell lesions associated with hyperparathyroidism. The lesions are expansile and lytic with a 'soap bubble' centre and well-demarcated edges.

Reference: Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, 7th edition, Page no 1655

questions.text: Middle meningeal artery passes through which of the following foramen?
questions.solution:
• The foramen spinosum is small and circular in shape.
  • It is situated posterolateral to the foramen ovale.
  • It is limited posterolaterally by the spine of sphenoid.
  • The foramen spinosum transmits
    • The middle meningeal artery
    • The meningeal branch of the mandibular nerve or nervus spinosus
    • The posterior trunk of the middle meningeal vein.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 3, 8th Edition, Page No 15, 19

questions.text: Which enzymatic mutation is responsible for immortality of cancer cells :
questions.solution:
• Telomerase is one of several factors that contribute to the endless replicative capacity (the immortalization) of cancer cells.
  • Cancer cells have developed mechanisms to evade apoptosis, and thus of continuing to grow and divide. In general, these mechanisms involve mutations that cause loss of function of proteins that are proapoptotic, or from overexpression of antiapoptotic genes.
  • One such example concerns loss of function of the P53 gene, perhaps the most commonly mutated gene in cancers. Resultant loss of upregulation of proapoptotic BAX shifts the balance in favour of antiapoptotic proteins.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, page no 734-735

questions.text: A 58-yr old patient presents with congestive cardiac failure. She is a known patient of rheumatoid arthritis for 30 yrs. Her endomyocardial biopsy with Congo red stain viewed with polarised light is shown in the image. Which protein is likely to be deposited?
questions.solution:
• AA amyloidosis is caused by the deposition of serum amyloid A (SAA) protein, which results from chronic inflammation in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Congo red stain, when viewed with polarized light, shows an apple-green birefringence due to the cross-β structure of amyloid fibrils.
  • The presence of Congo red-positive amyloid deposits in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis strongly indicates AA amyloidosis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 261-262

questions.text: The pathogenicity of Entamoeba histolytica is indicated by-
questions.solution:
• There are distinct invasive and non-invasive strains of E histolytica. These strains vary according to their isoenzyme patterns (zymodemes).
  • E. histolytica strains have 22 zymodemes of which 10 are invasive and 12 are non-invasive.
  • Zymodemes of E. histolytica are identified according to the electrophoretic mobility of 4 enzymes.
  1. L-malate: NADP+ Oxidoreductase
  2. Phosphoglucomutase (PGM)
  3. Glucose-phosphate isomerase

4 Hexokinase

  • Electrophoresis of PGM can show one or more of the 4 bands: a. B. Y and & Strains of E. histolytica showing, an absence of a-band together with the presence of β band are virulent Le, invasive.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology 8th edition, Page no 18, 21

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acting via histaminergic system is approved for Narcolepsy?
questions.solution:
• The H3 antagonists/inverse agonists have a wide range of central effects; for example, they promote wakefulness, improve cognitive function (e.g., enhance memory, learning, and attention), and reduce food intake. As a result, there is considerable interest in developing H3 antagonists for possible treatment of sleeping disorders, ADHD, epilepsy, cognitive impairment, schizophrenia, obesity, neuropathic pain, and Alzheimer disease. A number of other imidazole derivatives have been developed as H3 antagonists, including clobenpropit, ciproxifan, and proxyfan, but the imidazole ring enhances binding to the H4 receptor and CYPs. Because of this, more selective non imidazole H3 antagonists/inverse agonists (e.g., tiprolisant) were developed.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no 719

choices.text: Second left intercostal space near sternum
Second right intercostal space near sternum
Sixth left intercostal space near sternum
Sixth right intercostal space near sternum

questions.text: Pulmonary valve can be auscultated in which of the following area?
questions.solution:
The pulmonary valve is auscultated (listened to with a stethoscope) in the chest to assess heart sounds.

The pulmonary valve can be best auscultated in the second left intercostal space, which means it is found between the second rib on the left side and the sternum

The second right intercostal space is where the aortic valve is usually auscultated.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume;- 2, 8th Edition, Page No 333

choices.text: Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose or glycogen from noncarbohydrate precursors
Muscles are the major gluconeogenic tissues in the body
Kidney may contribute up to 40% of total glucose synthesis in the fasting state and more in starvation
The major substrates are the glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionate

questions.text: All of the following sentences are true about gluconeogenesis except:
questions.solution:
• Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose or glycogen from noncarbohydrate precursors.
  • The major substrates are the glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionate. Liver and kidney are the major gluconeogenic tissues; the kidney may contribute up to 40% of total glucose synthesis in the fasting state and more in starvation.
  • A supply of glucose is necessary especially for the nervous system and erythrocytes. After an overnight fast, glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis make approximately equal contributions to blood glucose; as glycogen reserves are depleted, so gluconeogenesis becomes progressively more important.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, page no 185-186

questions.text: Which of the following is not an oncogenic DNA virus?
questions.solution:
HCV is RNA virus.

  • Although not a DNA virus, HCV is also strongly linked to the pathogenesis of liver cancer. The molecular mechanisms used by HCV are less well defined than are those of HBV. In addition to chronic liver cell injury and compensatory regeneration, components of the HCV genome, such as the HCV core protein, may have a direct effect on tumorigenesis, possibly by activating a variety of growth promoting signal transduction pathways.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 327

questions.text: When Propofol and remifentanil are used in a patient, they produce anaesthetic effects greater than the effects caused by them used individually. This mechanism, when the combined action of two or more drugs is greater than the sum of their individual effects, it is called:
questions.solution:
Synergism occurs when the combined action of two or more drugs is greater than the sum of their individual effects (i.e. 1 + 1 > 2):

  • propofol and remifentanil

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no: 888, 2622, 2623, 2624, 2637, 2640

questions.text: Pott's puffy tumour is a complication of sinus disease related to:
questions.solution:
Pott's puffy tumour is a well-circumscribed swelling of the forehead caused by anterior extension of frontal sinusitis. The oedema of the skin and soft tissue overlies a collection of pus under the periosteum of the anterior table of the frontal sinus.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, page no 781

questions.text:
A Person Was Shot by Gun During the Quarrel in the Public Firing due to which He Was Injured and Presented to the OPD. A Diagnosis of Hemisection of Spinal Cord (Brown Sequard Syndrome) Was Made. Which of the Following Are Involved from Below?
1. Dorsal Column
2. Spinothalamic Tract
3. Corticospinal Tract
questions.solution:
• Damage to the dorsal columns leads to ipsilateral loss of the ability to detect light touch, vibration, and proprioception from body structures represented caudal to the level of damage.
  • Damage to the ventrolateral spinothalamic pathway leads to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion. Such spinal damage could occur with a penetrating wound or a tumour.
  • A functional hemisection of the spinal cord causes a characteristic and easily recognized clinical picture that reflects damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Sequard syndrome.
  • The lesion to fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion. The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.
  • Damage to the corticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition, Page no 227-253

questions.text: Which among the following is a cardio protective fatty acid?
questions.solution:
Significance of Omega3 Fatty Acid

  • Decrease the risk of Cardiovascular Disease
  • Appear to replace arachidonic acid in platelet membranes
  • Lower the production of thromboxane and tendency of the platelet aggregation
  • Decrease Serum Triglycerides
  • Important for Infant Development
  • Lower the risk of various mental illness (Depression, ADHD)
  • Lower the risk of chronic degenerative diseases such as Cancer, Rheumatoid Arthritis, and Alzheimer's Disease.

Following are Omega 3 Fatty Acid

  • α Linolenic Acid
  • Timnodonic Acid (Eicosapentaenoic Acid)
  • Cervonic Acid (DocosaHexaenoic Acid- DHA)

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, page no 239

questions.text: Serum levels of which of the following can be used to distinguish Iron deficiency anaemia (IDA) from Iron refractory iron deficiency anaemia (IRIDA)?
questions.solution:
Option B & C: In IRIDA, there is normal to borderline low ferritin levels and increased hepcidin. In IDA, the serum ferritin level is decreased in all stages of ID and can be the first indication of a developing ID state. Hepcidin is decreased.

Option A & D: Patients with IRIDA show microcytic anaemia (MCV 45-65fL; haemoglobin 6-9 g/dL) and hypoferremia with very low transferrin saturation (less than 5%). In IDA, serum iron is decreased, usually less than 30 mcg/dL, the TIBC is increased, and transferrin saturation is decreased to less than 15%.

Reference: Clinical laboratory haematology by Shirlyn McKenzie, 4th edition, Page no 243, 247

questions.text: Commonest cause of nosocomial infection are all except
questions.solution:
• Initially hospital outbreaks were caused by Gram positive organisms like streptococcus pyogenes and MRSA. Presently gram-negative enteric pathogens (Enterobacteriaceae) including E coli, Klebsiella and Enterobacter species have emerged as an important cause.
  • Pseudomonas and Acinetobacter species are also common nosocomial pathogens and are extremely resistant to common antibiotics and antiseptics.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 606-610

questions.text: A 15 years old patient with multiple small pituitary tumours that overproduced growth hormone underwent surgical removal of the tumour. The resection was found to be incomplete. What is the first line of management in this patient afterwards?
questions.solution:
• Octreotide- This synthetic octapeptide surrogate of somatostatin is 40 times more potent in suppressing GH secretion and longer acting (t½ ~90 min), but only a weak inhibitor of insulin secretion.
  • It is preferred over somatostatin for acromegaly and secretory diarrhoea associated with carcinoid, AIDS, cancer chemotherapy or diabetes. Control of diarrhoea is due to suppression of hormones which enhance intestinal mucosal secretion.
  • Adverse effects are abdominal pain, nausea, steatorrhoea, diarrhoea, and gallstones (due to biliary stasis).
  • Hyperglycaemia is infrequent. Octreotide injected i.v. (100 μg followed by 25-50 μg/hr) reduces hepatic blood flow and helps stop esophageal variceal bleeding.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 260

questions.text: Which nucleus of the hypothalamus is primarily responsible for regulating circadian rhythms and is located bilaterally above the optic chiasm?
questions.solution:
The centre of circadian rhythm is the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) of hypothalamus. SCN is so named for its location bilaterally above the optic chiasm. For its major influence on physiological alterations in diurnal rhythm, SCN is designated as the biological clock.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page no 278

questions.text: The following post mortem change is associated with which poisoning?
questions.solution:
Cherry Red coloured lividity is seen with Carbon monoxide poisoning.

Opium: Greyish/ Black hypostasis

Phosphorous: Dark brown

Potassium chlorate: Chocolate brown

Cyanide: Brick Red

Septic abortion: Pale bronze

References: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, page no 155-159

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not associated with HLA-B27 positivity?
questions.solution:
• Ankylosing spondylitis, reactive arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, and undifferentiated spondyloarthropathy are all HLA-B27 associated diseases that may all be associated with anterior uveitis.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis does not have a strong Class I HLA association, and is more typically associated with scleritis or keratitis than anterior uveitis.
  • HLA B-27 Positivity group which comprises ankylosing spondylitis, undifferentiated spondyloarthropathy, psoriatic arthritis, reactive arthritis (Reiter syndrome) and spondyloarthropathy with inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease). They are often referred to as seronegative spondyloarthropathies, in that rheumatoid factor is not present and the pathophysiological basis differs.

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 435

questions.text: Tumor extends to invade cribriform plate in carcinoma of nasal cavity and ethmoid will be?
questions.solution:
T stage describes the extent of the primary tumor.

N stage describes the extent of nodal involvement.

M stage describes the presence or absence of distant metastasis.

Reference: Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, 7th edition, Page no 2424

questions.text: At which of the following levels, veins of the pampiniform plexus condenses into two veins?
questions.solution:
• The veins emerging from the testes form the pampiniform plexus (pampiniform = like a vine).
  • The anterior part of the plexus is arranged around the testicular artery, the middle part around the ductus deferens and its artery, and the posterior part is isolated.
  • The plexus condenses into four veins at the superficial inguinal ring, and into two veins at the deep inguinal ring.
  • These veins accompany the testicular artery.
  • Ultimately one vein is formed which drains into the inferior vena cava on the right side, and into the left renal vein on the left side.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume- 2, 8th Edition, Page No 264

choices.text: Parvovirus infection in patient with sickle cell anaemia

questions.text: Acute acquired pure red cell aplasia is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Viral (parvovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and viral hepatitis) and/or bacterial infections can be associated with a temporary suppression of erythropoiesis. B19 parvovirus infects erythroid progenitor cells, lyses the target cell, and blocks erythropoiesis.

Other options: Chronic acquired red cell aplasia usually occurs in association with thymoma, autoimmune hemolytic anaemia, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, or hematologic neoplasms (MDS, large granular lymphocytic leukaemia, chronic lymphoid leukaemia, Hodgkin disease).

Reference: Clinical laboratory haematology by Shirlyn McKenzie, 4th edition, Page no 356-357

questions.text: In which stage of filariasis are microfilaria seen in peripheral blood-
questions.solution:
• The inflammatory phase is characterised by Lymphangitis, lymphadenitis and adenolymphangitis.
  • It lasts for a few days, then subsides spontaneously & recurs at irregular intervals for a period of weeks to months.
  • Although this is usually caused by inflammation of lymphatic vessels, due to the adult worm, blood may reveal the presence of microfilariae in the early phase

Remember

  1. bancrofti is nocturnally periodic i.e., microfilariae are scarce in peripheral blood by day and increase at night.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology 8th edition, Page no 210, 211

choices.text: Palpitations, chest pain, raised blood pressure

questions.text: A 30 years old patient was started on lithium carbonate for bipolar disorder. The nurse will give instructions on adverse effects of the therapy. The patient should report back immediately if the following features are seen:
questions.solution:
• Lithium is a monovalent cation used as a mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder.
  • It has a narrow safety margin and requires therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).
  • Its full effect takes 1-2 weeks, and it's the drug of choice for bipolar disorder prophylaxis.
  • Lithium has documented anti-suicidal properties in bipolar disorder. In acute mania, it can be used with benzodiazepines or antipsychotics for faster action.
  • For maintenance therapy, plasma concentration should be 0.5-0.8 mEq/L, and for acute mania, 0.8-1.2 mEq/L. Toxic symptoms appear if plasma levels exceed 1.5 mEq/L.
  • Diuretics, especially thiazides, can reduce renal excretion of lithium, leading to toxicity. Adverse effects include acne, weight gain (due to Na+ and water retention), and T wave elevation in ECG.
  • Lithium toxicity symptoms include vomiting, tremors, ataxia, coma, and convulsions.
  • Severe toxicity leads to confusion, hyperreflexia, seizures, and even death.
  • No specific antidote for lithium; dialysis is used in acute or chronic overdose with specific serum levels.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 476

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with fatigue and difficulty breathing. His complete blood count reveals a low hemoglobin level. A peripheral blood smear shows sickle-shaped red blood cells. What is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hemoglobin electrophoresis is the most appropriate next step that separates the different types of hemoglobin and identifies the presence of abnormal hemoglobin such as hemoglobin S, which is characteristic of sickle cell anemia.
  • Bone marrow biopsy may be useful in diagnosing other types of anemia.
  • Chest X-ray or abdominal ultrasound may be helpful in evaluating complications of sickle cell anemia.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, page no 446-450

questions.text: Opening of nasal fistulas is most commonly located at?
questions.solution:
The fistula opening is most commonly located on the nasal dorsum, rarely at the columella.

Reference: Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, 7th edition, Page no 1503

questions.text: Repair of DNA damage is very critical in maintaining genome integrity. Which of the following is not a single base alteration ?
questions.solution:
Types of Damage to DNA

I. Single-base alteration

A. Depurination

B. Deamination of cytosine to uracil

C. Deamination of adenine to hypoxanthine

D. Alkylation of base

E. Base-analog incorporation

II. Two-base alteration

A. UV light-induced thymine-thymine (pyrimidine) dimer

B. Bifunctional alkylating agent cross-linkage

III. Chain breaks

A. Ionizing radiation

B. Radioactive disintegration of backbone element

C. Oxidative free radical formation

IV. Cross-linkage

A. Between bases in same or opposite strands

B. Between DNA and protein molecules (eg, histones)

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, page no 389

choices.text: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation
Contralateral loss of crude touch and pressure
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation
Ipsilateral loss of crude touch and pressure

questions.text: Injury to lateral spinothalamic tract leads to:
questions.solution:
• The anterior and lateral spinothalamic tracts carry exteroceptive sensations from the opposite half of body
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract: This tract carries the sensation of pain and temperature. The first neuron fibres start in the dorsal root ganglia.
    • These relay by synapsing with neurons lying in the grey matter of laminae II and III.
    • Pain fibres relay in lamina II (substantia gelatinosa).
    • The second neuron fibres cross immediately to the opposite side close to the central canal and ascend as a tract in the lateral white column of the spinal cord.
  • Anterior spinothalamic tract: This tract carries the fibres for crude touch and pressure, tickle and itch.
    • First neuron fibres are in the dorsal root ganglia.
    • These relay in the grey matter of posterior horn or nucleus proprius (laminae III and IV).
    • The second neuron fibres ascend for 1-2 segments and cross to the opposite side in the white commissure and ascend as a tract in the anterior white column of the spinal cord.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume -; 4, 8th Edition, Page No 45, 47

questions.text: Branched chain keto acid decarboxylation is defective in:
questions.solution:
Maple Syrup Urine Disease Biochemical defect

  • Deficiency of the enzyme Branched Chain Ketoacid Dehydrogenase.
  • Defective reaction is Defective Decarboxylation.

Clinical features

  • Mental Retardation
  • Convulsion
  • Acidosis, Coma
  • Smell of Burnt Sugar [Maple Syrup]

Tests for MSUD

  • Di Nitro Phenyl Hydrazine Test (DNPH Test)
  • Rothera's Test
  • Enzyme Analysis

Treatment

  • Restrict Branched Chain Amino Acid
  • Give high doses of Thiamine.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, page no 309-310

questions.text: Image shows autopsy findings in the colon of a 35-yr old male. Similar findings were observed in many organs. Patient had severe thrombocytopenia and died of intracerebral haemorrhage. Which term best describes the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Option C: Image shows punctate petechial haemorrhages of the colonic mucosa, a consequence of thrombocytopenia. Petechiae are minute 1 to 2 mm haemorrhages.

Option A: Ecchymoses (sometimes simply called bruises) are haemorrhages of 1 to 2 cm in size.

Option B: Congested tissues have an abnormal blue-red colour (cyanosis) that stems from the accumulation of deoxygenated haemoglobin in the affected area.

Option D: Purpura are slightly larger (≥3 mm) than petechiae.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 117,125

questions.text: Wood's light can be used for evaluation of -
questions.solution:
A wood's lamp generates 360-nm UV light.

It is used in the evaluation of:

Tinea Capitis- Freckles

- Erythrasma- Tinea Versicolor

Wounds colonised by Pseudomonas- Ash leaf spots in patients with tuberous sclerosis. In tuberous sclerosis also it is not used.

For Vitiligo it is not used.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, page 602, 603

questions.text: A 25 years old female, status post mural valve replacement requires an emergency laparoscopic surgery for torsion ovary. She is on warfarin for the prosthetic valve. All of the following drugs can potentate or increase the effects of warfarin and cause risk of bleeding, except:
questions.solution:
• Warfarin is extensively protein bound (>95%). Therefore, any drug that competes for the protein binding site, or any condition that reduces protein binding, will potentiate the activity of warfarin. NSAIDS and simvastatin if administered concurrently with warfarin compete for the plasma protein binding sites, leading to warfarin displacement and increased warfarin anticoagulant effect.
  • There are also various drugs that affect the metabolism of warfarin such as metronidazole, macrolides and alcohol. All of these reduce its metabolism, raise the INR and increase the risk of bleeding.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no: 1098, 1126

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is expected to increase when the patient is on aspirin?
questions.solution:
• Antiplatelet drugs (like aspirin and clopidogrel) prolong the bleeding time.
  • Anticoagulant drugs prolong the clotting time.
  • Drugs interfering with intrinsic pathway (like heparin) prolong the aPTT.
  • Drugs interfering with extrinsic pathways (like warfarin) prolong the PT.
  • Thrombin time is prolonged in cases of afibrinogenemia and dysfibrinogenemia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 677

questions.text: Which of the following constitutes a pertinent clinical feature of neovascular AMD?
questions.solution:
Neovascular AMD is characterised by the development of choroidal neovascularization. This exudative neovascular complex commonly results in the accumulation of subretinal fluid. Drusen, retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) pigmentary changes, and geographic RPE atrophy are characteristics of non-neovascular AMD.

Reference: Kanski clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page no 580

questions.text: A 30-year-old recent immigrant from Central America presents with long-standing nasal obstruction, purulent rhinorrhea, and crusting. Physical examination demonstrates blue-red rubbery granulomas of the nasal mucosa, as well as broadening of the nasal dorsum. Some parts of the nasal airway appear fibrotic. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The features described are consistent with the granulomatous and fibrotic stages of rhinoscleroma. Broadening of the nasal dorsum produces the characteristic Hebra nose.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, page no 645

questions.text: Zinc is an important metal in the human body. It is a cofactor for:
questions.solution:
Metal ions constitute the most common type of prosthetic group. Roughly one-third of all enzymes that contain tightly bound Fe, Co, Cu, Mg, Mn, and Zn are termed metalloenzymes. Metal ions that participate in redox reactions generally are complexed to prosthetic groups such as heme or iron-sulphur clusters. Metals also may facilitate the binding and orientation of substrates, the formation of covalent bonds with reaction intermediates (Co2+ in coenzyme B1), or by acting as Lewis acids or bases to render substrates more electrophilic (electron-poor) or nucleophilic (electron-rich), and hence more reactive.

Zinc acts as coenzyme in following enzymes

Carbonic Anhydrase

  • CarboxyPeptidase
  • Lactate Dehydrogenase
  • Alcohol Dehydrogenase
  • Alkaline Phosphatase

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, page no 62

choices.text: Increased insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism

questions.text: Sirtuins are responsible for?
questions.solution:
• Sirtuins are a family of NAD-dependent protein deacetylases. Sirtuins increase insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism, and may be targets for the treatment of diabetes.
  • Sirtuins are thought to promote the expression of several genes whose products increase longevity. These include proteins that inhibit metabolic activity, reduce apoptosis, stimulate protein folding, and counteract the harmful effects of oxygen free radicals.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 68

choices.text: It is seen in only immunocompromised individuals

questions.text: Select the false statement about P. jiroveci-
questions.solution:
Option 'a'

-See following statements of Topley's mycology.

"Pneumocystis are found in low numbers in the lungs of mammalian hosts with intact immune system and in more abundance in homeotherms with compromised immune status".

"A decrease in cell mediated immunity is the single most important risk factor for the development of pneumocystis pneumonia".

-So, P. jiroveci may be seen both in immunocompromised individuals and individuals with intact immune systems, but it causes pneumonia only in immunocompromised individuals.

Option 'b'

P. jiroveci may be associated with CMV infection but it is not usually associated with CMV infection.

Option "c"

-P. jirovecii may be associated with pneumatocele formation but pneumatoceles are not associated in all cases of P Jirovecii pneumonia.

Option 'd'

Option 'c' is partially correct.

-Usually, the diagnosis of pneumocystis pneumonia is confirmed by histopathological staining of BAL fluid collected by bronchoscopy, but it can also be diagnosed by microscopic examination of induced sputum.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 618

choices.text: Injecting intracameral triamcinolone to identify vitreous in the anterior chamber for anterior vitrectomy
Continue to phacoemulsification of the lens in the anterior vitreous to minimize amount of lens falling back
Injecting viscoelastic device (OVD) posterior to the nucleus to lift into anterior chamber, if possible
Placing sulcus IOL and closing the wound with referral to a vitreoretinal specialist for removal of retained lens fragment

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is inappropriate in managing a dropped nucleus intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
• Continuing to phaco in the vitreous is inappropriate in managing a dropped nucleus intraoperatively because it may cause traction on the retina causing retinal tears or breaks and add additional risk for retinal detachment.

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 325, 326

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities of immune function is seen in AIDS?
questions.solution:
Option D: Plasma cells increase in number, leading to hypergammaglobulinemia and bone marrow plasmacytosis.

Option A: Lymphopenia is predominantly caused by death of the CD4+ helper T-cell subset.

Option B & C: IL-2 and IFN-γ production as well as cytotoxicity decreases due to altered T-cell function.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 252

questions.text: A 30 years old patient has presented with acute abdominal pain. He was diagnosed with acute appendicitis and is scheduled for surgery. He has a history of porphyria in the family. Which of the following drugs can be used safely:
questions.solution:
Propofol can be safely used, while the remaining drugs are contraindicated in porphyria. They may cause an acute porphyric crisis.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 832, 851

questions.text: Which of the following Antidepressants has the least sexual side effects?
questions.solution:
• Mirtazapine This antidepressant acts by a novel mechanism, viz. blocks α2 auto- (on NA neurons) and hetero- (on 5-HT neurons) receptors enhancing both NA and 5-HT release.
  • Accordingly, it has been labelled as 'noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant' (NaSSA).
  • Increased appetite and weight gain is frequent. Sexual dysfunction is not a problem with mirtazapine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no 490

questions.text: Juvenile Angiofibroma is associated with mutation of which gene?
questions.solution:
Juvenile angiofibroma have also been reported to develop 25 times more frequently in patients with familial adenomatous polyposis, a condition that is associated with mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene.

Reference: Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, 7th edition, Page no 2438

questions.text: A 60-yr old man has hypertension since 15 yrs. His HbA2 level is 10.2%. His urine analysis report shows 1+ proteinuria with no evidence of RBCs. On USG examination, size of both kidneys is reduced. An image of his renal biopsy is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• As seen in image, the arteriolar wall is thickened with increased protein deposition (hyalinized), and the lumen is markedly narrowed. It is more generalised and severe in patients with hypertension and diabetes. In nephrosclerosis due to chronic hypertension, the arteriolar narrowing causes diffuse impairment of renal blood supply and glomerular scarring.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 492

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with history of rashes, self mutilation, family history positive which of the following investigations do you think may be suggestive of valuable for diagnosis:
questions.solution:
While purine deficiency states are rare in human subjects, there are numerous genetic disorders of purine catabolism. Hyperuricemia may be differentiated based on whether patients excrete normal or excessive quantities of total urates.

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome

  • The Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, an overproduction hyperuricemia characterised by frequent episodes of uric acid lithiasis and a bizarre syndrome of self-mutilation, reflects a defect in hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase, an enzyme of purine salvage.
  • The accompanying rise in intracellular PRPP results in purine overproduction.
  • Mutations that decrease or abolish hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase activity include deletions, frameshift mutations, base substitutions, and aberrant mRNA splicing.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, page no 354-355.

questions.text: Hydrolysis by plasma cholinesterase is the primary elimination route of all the following drugs except
questions.solution:
Plasma cholinesterase (PChE), also known as pseudocholinesterase, butyrylcholinesterase, or serum cholinesterase, is a serine hydrolase from the family of human cholinesterases. Anaesthetic drugs metabolized by PChE include succinylcholine, mivacurium, and all ester local anaesthetics (e.g., cocaine, procaine, and chloroprocaine).

PChE is produced in the liver, and its plasma half-life is approximately 8 to 12 days.

Advanced age, pregnancy, chronic kidney failure, or specific gene variations may result in reduced PChE activity.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no 1635, 1636

questions.text: A female patient with macrocytic anaemia and achlorhydria diagnosed with B12 deficiency. Which of the following cells are chiefly involved in the following condition?
questions.solution:
Parietal cells (oxyntic cells) are acidophilic. These cells line predominantly the upper half of glands and have an extensive intracellular canalicular system. These secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl), the intrinsic factor. Due to the deficiency of intrinsic factor, absorption of Vitamin B12 is affected markedly, and there may occur pernicious anaemia.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology, 25th Edition, Page no 164

choices.text: Indenting of the cornea during A-scan measurement
Too little applanation pressure during A-Scan

questions.text: Three weeks after uncomplicated phacoemulsification and insertion of a 5.5-mm all-polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) posterior chamber lens in the capsular bag, a patient's refraction is +1.50 D in an eye that was planned to be plano postoperatively. Keratometry shows no astigmatism. Which of the following is most likely to have contributed to this result?
questions.solution:
• Poor applanation technique during A-scan measurement can result in incorrect measurement of the eye's axial length.
  • Too much pressure may yield a falsely shallow anterior chamber depth, with an axial length that is inaccurately short.
  • Too little applanation pressure may result in a fluid bridge between the tip of the probe and the cornea, which results in a falsely long anterior chamber depth as well as a falsely elongated total axial length. If an axial length measurement is falsely elongated due to poor applanation technique, the surgeon may implant an intraocular lens with too little power for the eye, resulting in a hyperopic postoperative correction. Lens-induced myopia should have no effect on the true axial length of the eye. Likewise, a posterior vitreous detachment should not affect the postoperative refraction.

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 316, 335

choices.text: Always produce collapse of the bridge
Are often associated with the use of topical nasal corticosteroids

questions.text: Septal perforations
questions.solution:
• The most common cause of septal perforations is trauma that may be self-inflicted or iatrogenic. However, malignant T-cell lymphomas can produce destructive lesions in the midline and should be treated after full staging with a full course of radiotherapy. They may be associated with Epstein-Barr virus.
  • Collapse of the bridge may occur, particularly in association with granulomatous diseases or after trauma and surgery, although this is by no means a constant occurrence.
  • The edges of the perforation may be associated with crusting, and this, together with the turbulence of inspired air, can produce a sensation of congestion or nasal blockage.
  • However, many patients are unaware that a perforation is present. The evidence that nasal corticosteroids cause septal perforations is entirely circumstantial, and there are only a couple of well-documented case reports in the literature. Unfortunately, the short and longterm results of surgical closure are only moderately successful.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, page no 752

questions.text: Toxicity of Ethanol is due to:
questions.solution:
• High concentration of NADH leads to high NADH/NAD+ ratio. This is the basic cause of all metabolic alteration in alcoholism.
  • Ethanol Also Causes Fatty Liver
  • Alcoholic fatty liver is the first stage in alcoholic liver disease (ALD) which is caused by alcoholism and ultimately leads to cirrhosis. The fat accumulation in the liver is caused by a combination of impaired fatty acid oxidation and increased lipogenesis, which is thought to be due to changes in the [NADH]/ [NAD+] redox potential in the liver, and also to interference with the action of transcription factors regulating the expression of the enzymes involved in the pathways.
  • Oxidation of ethanol by alcohol dehydrogenase leads to excess production of NADH, which competes with reducing equivalents from other substrates, including fatty acids, for the respiratory chain.
  • This inhibits their oxidation and causes increased esterification of fatty acids to form triacylglycerol, resulting in the fatty liver. Oxidation of ethanol leads to the formation of acetaldehyde, which is oxidised by aldehyde dehydrogenase, producing acetate.
  • The increased (NADH)/(NAD+) ratio also causes increased (lactate)/(pyruvate), resulting in hyperlacticacidemia, which decreases excretion of uric acid, aggravating gout.
  • Some metabolism of ethanol takes place via a cytochrome P450-dependent microsomal ethanol oxidising system (MEOS) involving NADPH and O2. This system increases in activity in chronic alcoholism and may account for the increased metabolic clearance in this condition.
  • Ethanol also inhibits the metabolism of some drugs, eg, barbiturates, by competing for cytochrome P450-dependent enzymes.
  • In some Asian populations and Native Americans, alcohol consumption results in increased adverse reactions to acetaldehyde owing to a genetic defect of mitochondrial aldehyde dehydrogenase.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, page no 261.

questions.text: Which of the following types of graft rejections is mediated by the complement system?
questions.solution:
Option C: In acute antibody-mediated (vascular, or humoral) rejection, antibodies bind to vascular endothelium and activate complement via the classical pathway.

Option A: Hyperacute rejection is mediated by preformed antibodies specific for antigens on graft endothelial cells.

Option B: In acute cellular rejection, CD8+ CTLs may directly destroy graft cells, or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines and induce inflammation, which damages the graft.

Option D: In chronic rejection, the culprit is believed to be T cells that react against graft alloantigens and secrete cytokines, which stimulate the proliferation and activities of fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells in the graft. Alloantibodies also contribute to chronic rejection.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 235-237

questions.text: Man is the definitive host for -
questions.solution:

Parasites that have humans as intermediate hosts:
