questions.text: 57 years old male patient having persistent hyperglycaemia since past 15 years reports to the Emergency dept. On physical examination, he is found dehydrated and BP is 90/70 mmHg. Urine examination reveals high concentration of glucose along with excretion of ketone bodies. What could be the type of respiration in a given case?
questions.solution:
The pattern of respiration seen in diabetic ketoacidosis is called Kussmaul breathing. Accumulation of metabolic acids such as acetoacetic acid and β-hydroxy butyric acid produces metabolic Acidosis that stimulates respiratory centres which leads to rapid and deep respiration or 'air hunger' as described by Kussmaul.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology, 26th Edition, Page no 431

questions.text: The only test which can detect both choline and spermine in a seminal stain is
questions.solution:
Tests for Semen:

  • Florence test: Stain extracted with 1% hydrochloric acid and Florence solution. Presence of semen indicated by dark-brown choline iodide crystals.
  • Barberio's test: Saturated picric acid solution added to spermatic fluid. Presence of spermine detected by yellow rhombic crystals.
  • Acid phosphatase test: Measures acid phosphatase activity in semen, commonly used for detection.
  • Creatine phosphokinase levels: Levels >400/ml almost diagnostic of semen.
  • Thin layer chromatography: Detects choline and spermine in seminal stain.

Other tests: Microscopy, staining, protein precipitation, and Prostate-specific antigen (P30).

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 406

questions.text: Which types of post translational modification of histone affects gene expression?
questions.solution:
EPIGENETIC MECHANISMS ARE INVOLVED IN CANCER

  • There is growing evidence that epigenetic mechanisms are involved in the causation of cancer. Such mechanisms produce non mutational changes that affect regulation of gene expression.
  • Methylation of specific cytosine bases in genes is implicated in turning off the activities of certain genes. Changes from normal in methylation/demethylation of cytosine residues in specific genes have been detected in cancer cells.
  • Post translational modifications of histones, such as acetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, and ubiquitylation also affect gene expression.
  • Changes in acetylation of histones H3 and H4 that affect gene transcription, have been found in cancer cells.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, page no 735

questions.text: A 60-yr old man has sudden-onset chest pain and dyspnea. On examination, heart rate is increased. Laboratory studies show raised D-dimer levels. He succumbs to death. On autopsy, red infarct is seen as shown in the image. Which of the following organs can show this type of red infarct?
questions.solution:
Option D: Red infarcts occur (1) with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion), (2) in loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung) where blood can collect in the infarcted zone, (3) in tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine) that allow blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone, (4) in tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow, and (5) when flow is reestablished to a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction).

Other options: White infarcts occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation (e.g., heart, spleen, and kidney), and where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 133

questions.text: A 30 years old patient of acute schizophrenia was prescribed haloperidol 3 months back. For the last two days, he has become restless and has been roaming around in the room for a day. On examination he was found to have tremors of hand. He is most likely to be suffering from:
questions.solution:
Continuous purposeless to and fro movement without anxiety is called akathisia. It is an extrapyramidal syndrome caused by D2 blockers like haloperidol.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 471

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for inhibiting gastrointestinal motility?
questions.solution:
The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for inhibiting gastrointestinal motility through the release of norepinephrine. The vagus nerve, splanchnic nerve, and pelvic nerve all play a role in stimulating gastrointestinal motility.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, page no 797-806

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with sudden onset pain and redness in the right eye. On examination, his right cornea shows a dendritic ulcer with terminal bulbs and a surrounding area of stromal haze. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• The presentation of sudden onset pain and redness with a dendritic ulcer with terminal bulbs and a surrounding area of stromal haze suggests herpes simplex keratitis as the most likely diagnosis.
  • Herpes simplex keratitis is a common cause of dendritic ulcers and is often associated with a history of recurrent episodes.
  • Fungal keratitis may present with a similar picture, but it is less likely to have terminal bulbs and more likely to have a feathery or irregular edge.
  • Bacterial keratitis may also present with a dendritic ulcer, but it is less common and is typically associated with a central, circular ulcer.
  • Acanthamoeba keratitis may present with a dendritic-shaped ulcer, but it typically has a ring-shaped infiltrate.

Reference: Kanaki clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 218

questions.text: In which parasitic infestation sputum examination is not of much value -
questions.solution:
• Sputum examination may be of value in these organisms.
  • Trichuris trichiura never passes through the lung, so sputum examination is of no use.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology 8th edition, Page no 123, 136, 137, 188, 201, 202

questions.text: A 62-yr old man complains of fever, headache and myalgia. He also complains of diplopia for a few days. He has lost 3 kgs recently. On examination, there is temporal palpation and a bruit. His laboratory investigations show raised ESR, 100 mm/hr. An image from his temporal artery biopsy is shown below. His symptoms are resolved with corticosteroids. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis).

Image shows section of temporal artery showing giant cells at the degenerated internal elastic membrane in active arteritis.

  • Temporal arteritis is rare before age 50. Symptoms may be only vague and constitutional-fever, fatigue, weight loss-or may involve facial pain or headache, most intense along the course of the superficial temporal artery, which can be painful to palpation.
  • Ocular symptoms range from diplopia to complete vision loss.
  • The treatment for giant cell arteritis is corticosteroids.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 511-512

questions.text: Patient undergone a removal of lower third molar tooth. After a week there was a loss of sensation in anterior two third of the tongue. Which of the following nerve can be injuired?
questions.solution:
• Lingual nerve lies in contact with mandible, medial to the third molar tooth.
  • In extraction of malplaced 'wisdom' tooth, care must be taken not to injure the lingual nerve.
  • Its injury results in loss of all sensations from anterior twothirds of the tongue.
  • During extraction of the 3rd molar, the buccal nerve may get involved by the local anaesthesia causing temporary numbness of the cheek.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 3, 8th Edition, Page No 136

questions.text: A 35-year old male complains of cough and dyspnea. He was recently diagnosed with bacterial pneumonia and prescribed antibiotics. On X-ray radiography, patchy subpleural areas of consolidation are noted. His biopsy shows connective tissue bodies (Masson bodies) as shown in the images (in low power and high power) below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cryptogenic organising pneumonia is most often seen as a response to infection or inflammatory injury of the lungs. It has been associated with viral and bacterial pneumonias, inhaled toxins, drugs, connective tissue disease, and graft versus-host disease in hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients. Patients present with cough and dyspnea and have patchy subpleural or peribronchial areas of airspace consolidation radiographically. Histologically, it is characterised by the presence of polypoid plugs of loose organising connective tissue (Masson bodies) within alveolar ducts, alveoli, and often bronchioles.

Option A: On the basis of its histology, nonspecific interstitial pneumonia is divided into cellular and fibrosing patterns. The cellular pattern consists primarily of mild to moderate chronic interstitial inflammation, containing lymphocytes and a few plasma cells, in a uniform or patchy distribution. The fibrosing pattern consists of diffuse or patchy interstitial fibrotic lesions of roughly the same stage of development, an important distinction from UIP.

Option B: Microscopically, the hallmark of IPF is patchy interstitial fibrosis. The earliest lesions contain an exuberant proliferation of fibroblasts (fibroblastic foci). With time these areas become more fibrotic and less cellular. The dense fibrosis causes the destruction of alveolar architecture and the formation of cystic spaces lined by hyperplastic type II pneumocytes or bronchiolar epithelium (honeycomb fibrosis).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 690

questions.text: Which of the following options correctly represent the increasing order of potency of inhalational anaesthetic agents?
questions.solution:
Two important properties of an inhalational agent:

  • Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)
  • Blood gas partition coefficient.
  • Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC): Measures potency of an inhalational anesthetic agent. It is the minimum concentration of the agent in the alveoli that is required to produce unresponsiveness to the skin incision in 50% of patients.
  • Greater is the MAC, lesser is the potency.
  • Nitrous oxide is a gas with maximum MAC and thus least potency. Its MAC is 104% i.e., even with pure (100%) nitric oxide alone, we cannot get complete anaesthesia. This is why nitrous oxide is not a complete anesthetic agent.
  • The MAC of methoxyflurane is 0.16%, which means that it is the most potent inhalational anesthetic agent (having least MAC).


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no 405

questions.text: Dissolved O2 is significantly decreased in which type of hypoxia, select the correct option from below?
questions.solution: Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page no 647

questions.text: Which method of homicide is shown in the following image?
questions.solution:
BURKING: Burking is a method of homicidal smothering and traumatic asphyxia. William Burke and William flare, made their living by digging up bodies from graveyards and supplying them to the medical schools for dissection. Later they killed 16 persons in Edinburgh during the years 1927 and 1928, and sold their bodies to Dr. Robert Knox for use as specimens in his anatomy classes. A victim usually alone or away from the family, was invited to their house and given alcohol. Then the victim was thrown to the ground and Burke used to kneel or sit on the chest and close the nose and mouth with his hands, and Hare used to pull him round the room by the feet.

Option A: SMOTHERING: This is a form of asphyxia which is caused by closing the external respiratory orifices either by the hand or by other means, or blocking up the cavities of the nose and mouth by the introduction of a foreign substance, such as mud, paper, cloth, etc.

Option B: GAGGING: This is a form of asphyxia which results from forcing a cloth into the mouth, or the closure of mouth and nose by a cloth or similar material, which is tied around the head.

Option C: MUGGING: Strangulation is caused by holding the neck of the victim in the bend of the elbow. Pressure is exerted either on front of the larynx, or at one or both sides of the neck by the forearm and upper arm. The attack is usually made from behind.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 359, 364

questions.text: A 7-month old infant was admitted with pallor. On laboratory investigations, Hb was 4 gm/dL, MCV was 65 fL and reticulocyte production index was 1.5. An image of his bone marrow aspiration stained with Prussian blue stain is shown below. He is treated with oral pyridoxine and responds well. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In sideroblastic anaemia, the anaemia is usually moderate to severe.

On peripheral smear, hypochromic macrocytes are especially prevalent in refractory anaemia with ring sideroblasts (RARS), whereas hypochromic microcytic are more common in the hereditary form of SA.

Even though the bone marrow is usually hyperplastic, the reticulocyte production index is less than 2, indicating that the anaemia has an ineffective erythropoietic component.

Bone marrow changes in sideroblastic anaemia include erythroid hyperplasia often accompanied by various degrees of megaloblastosis. Ring sideroblasts constitute more than 40% of the erythroblasts.

Reference: Clinical laboratory haematology by Shirlyn McKenzie, 4th edition, Page no 251-252

questions.text: Which of the component is not present in the oculomotor nerve fibres?
questions.solution:
Functional components of oculomotor nerve:

  • General somatic efferent fibres, for muscles of eyeball which help in its movements.
  • General visceral efferent or parasympathetic fibres, for contraction of pupil and accommodation.
  • General somatic afferent column carries proprioceptive fibres from the extraocular muscles to mesencephalic nucleus of trigeminal nerve.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 4, 8th Edition, Page No 69

choices.text: Blood culture positive for Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: A 25-yr old i.v. drug user has fever since 3 days. On examination, compass systolic and diastolic murmurs are noted. He also has splenomegaly and nail bed splinter haemorrhages. His lab investigations show raised CK-MB. 2 days later, he dies of sudden cardiac arrest. A photograph of his congenitally bicuspid aortic valve is shown below. Which of the following is a minor diagnostic criterion for diagnosis of the disease?
questions.solution:
Image shows acute endocarditis of congenitally bicuspid aortic valve (caused by Staphylococcus aureus) with extensive cuspal destruction and ring abscess (arrow).



Definitive diagnosis: 2 major, or 1 major + 3 minor, or 5 minor criteria

Possible diagnosis: 1 major +1 minor, or 3 minor.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 564

questions.text: What is the minimum legal age to give consent for general examination by a physician?
questions.solution:
Sec.89, I.P.C. A child under 12 years of age and an insane person cannot give valid consent to suffer any harm which may result from an act done in good faith and for its benefit. The consent of the parent or guardian should be taken. If they refuse, the doctor cannot treat the patient even to save the life.

Loco Parentis: In an emergency involving children. when their parents or guardians are not available, consent is taken from the person-in-charge of the child, e.g., a school teacher can give consent for treating a child who becomes sick during a picnic away from home town, or the consent of the headmaster of a residential school.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 50, 51

questions.text: Which junction allows the substance to pass through the cell membrane?
questions.solution:
Gap junctions are specialized intercellular connections or channels that allow direct communication and exchange of ions, small molecules, and signaling molecules between adjacent cells. These gap junctions form channels between the plasma membranes of two neighbouring cells and enable the passage of substances, such as ions and small molecules, from one cell to another. This direct cell-to-cell communication is crucial for coordinating various cellular activities and physiological processes in multicellular organisms.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology, 26th Edition, Page no 41, 43

choices.text: Presents as breast erythema, swelling and skin thickening
Poor prognosis due to distant metastasis

questions.text: Which of the following statements are not true regarding inflammatory carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option C: The name 'inflammatory' is a misnomer, as typically no inflammation is present. There is extensive plugging of the lymphovascular spaces of the dermis with carcinoma cells.

Option A & B: It presents as breast erythema, swelling, and skin thickening. The edematous skin is tethered to the breast by Cooper ligaments and mimics the surface of an orange peel, an appearance referred to as Peau d'orange.

Option D: These tumours are usually of high grade but do not belong to any particular molecular subtype. It carries a very poor prognosis as most patients prove to have distant metastases.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1058

questions.text: Transient colonization is caused by
questions.solution:
Skin and mucus membrane has 2 types of normal flora.

  • Transient flora - Consists of non-pathogenic or potentially pathogenic microorganism that inhabit the skin or mucous membrane for hours, days or weeks
  • It is derived from environment, does not produce disease and does not establish itself permanently on the surface
  • Transient flora is of little significance so long as the normal resident flora remains intact.
  • If the resident flora is disturbed transient microorganisms may colonize proliferate and produce disease
  • Membrane of transient flora - Microorganism other than CONS< Corynebacterium spp, micrococcus spp, bacillus spp, candida spp, trichomonas vaginalis, N meningitidis, CMV< HSV< malassezia, enterococcus, Bacteroides. M smegmats, Fusobacterium.
  • Resident flora -Consist of relatively fixed types of microorganism regularly found in a given are at a given age, if disturbed it promptly re-establishes itself and cannot be removed permanently

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 77, 209

questions.text: Schiller-Duval bodies may be seen in which of the following Tumours?
questions.solution:
In approximately 50% of yolk sac tumours, structures resembling endodermal sinuses (Schiller-Duval bodies) may be seen; these consist of a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells resembling primitive glomeruli.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th edition, Page no 972

questions.text: A farmer has an ulcer on leg with an indurated margin and multiple sinuses with discharging granules. The likely diagnosis is-
questions.solution:
Mycetoma (Maduramycosis)

  • Is a localized chronic granulomatous involvement of the subcutaneous and deeper tissues, commonly affecting the foot and less often the hand and other parts.
  • Presenting as a subcutaneous swelling with multiple discharging sinuses.
  • Sinuses discharge seropurulent fluid containing granules
  • These granules are microcolonies of the etiological agents.
  • A similar condition called botryomycosis is caused by staphylococcus aureus.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and paniker's microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 604,605,401

questions.text: Alpha-synuclein containing inclusions are seen in which disease?
questions.solution:
• The first mutations identified as a cause of autosomal dominant PD involved SNCA, a gene that encodes α-synuclein, an abundant lipid-binding protein normally localised to synapses. This protein is a major component of the Lewy body, which is the diagnostic hallmark of PD.
  • Like Aβ in AD, α-synuclein forms aggregates; of these, small oligomers appear to be the most toxic to neurons. α-synuclein-containing aggregates (Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites) are first seen in the medulla and then in contiguous areas of the brain, ascending through the brainstem and extending into limbic structures and finally the neocortex.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease 10th edition, Page no 1283

questions.text: A 28 years old female patient had 7 months of amenorrhea. On her antenatal visit her BP came 160/110 mmHg. We want to start medication for her hypertension. Which of the following drug is given to this patient?
questions.solution:
A blood pressure of ≥140/90 mmHg is abnormal and is associated with an increase in perinatal morbidity and mortality. The diagnosis of hypertension requires the measurement of two elevated blood pressures at least 4 hours apart.

Hypertension during pregnancy is classified as preeclampsia, gestational hypertension, or chronic hypertension.

ACE inhibitor, Angiotensin receptor blocker and Thiazide diuretics are associated with the foetal abnormality if taken during pregnancy.

So, these drugs are contraindicated in pregnancy.

Labetalol, Nifedipine, Methyldopa and Hydralazine are safe drugs used in pregnancy.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2083,3762

questions.text: A woman of 50 years who attained menopause, coming with one episode of bleeding P/V. All of the following to be done except:
questions.solution:
Causes of postmenopausal bleeding includes endometrial and vaginal atrophy, exogenous hormones (HRT), and tumors of the reproductive tract.

Investigations to rule out pathological causes include Pap smear, transvaginal sonography, hysteroscopy and biopsy, endometrial aspiration/ biopsy, and dilatation and curettage.

Dysfunctional uterine bleeding (DUB) is not relevant in postmenopausal bleeding as it refers to abnormal uterine bleeding in premenopausal women with anovulatory cycles.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th Edition, Page no 494

questions.text: All are the minimum standard for monitoring of the patients in the shock except
questions.solution:
Monitoring of patients in shock typically includes ECG (Electrocardiogram) to assess heart rhythm and activity, pulse oximetry to measure oxygen saturation, and blood pressure measurement to monitor perfusion. However, monitoring base deficit and serum lactate levels are not considered the minimum standard for monitoring patients in shock, although they can provide valuable information about tissue perfusion and oxygenation.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 18

questions.text: Which of the following is not a secondary skin lesion?
questions.solution:
Primary Skin Lesions: Papule, Plaque, Patch, Pustule, Tumor, Vesicle, Nodule, Bulla, Macule

Secondary Skin Lesions (Mnemonic: FUC SALE): Fissure, Ulcer, Crust, Scale, Atrophy, Lichenification, Excoriation, Erosion

Wheal is not a secondary skin lesion; it is a primary skin lesion characterized by a raised, transient, and pruritic area of the skin. It is commonly associated with allergic reactions and insect bites.

Reference: Rook′s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 4.12,101.1-101.2

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is not routinely administered in a 12 years old child?
questions.solution:
• Hepatitis A vaccine catch up vaccination can be done till 10 years of age. After that age, pre-vaccination screening of Hepatitis A antibody is recommended as at this age more than 50% of the population is seropositive.

Reference: IAP guidebook on immunization, 3rd edition, Page no 276

questions.text: Habit reversal is used for-
questions.solution:
For example, every time the person is aware of the urge to pull, they might put their hands in their pockets or be taught to make a tight fist until the urge passes.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no 294-297

choices.text: Absence of tenesmus and abdominal tenderness

questions.text: All of the following features help differentiate cholera from food poisoning except:
questions.solution:
Surface temperature is subnormal in cholera while it is increased in food poisoning.

Stools in cholera are copious, rice watery and inoffensive, while those in food poisoning may contain mucus and blood and may be offensive.

Tenesmus and abdominal tenderness are classically absent in cholera, while they may be present in food poisoning.

Muscle cramps in cholera are constant and severe, while they tend to be less constant in food poisoning.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page no 263

choices.text: Nonspecific interstitial pneumonitis related to collagen vascular disease

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman complained of dry cough and dyspnoea on exertion that has gradually worsened over 3 months. She started working in a pet store approximately 6 months ago. On physical examination, the patient appears well. The CXR is normal. A HRCT shows diffuse ground-glass infiltrates in the lower lobes with the presence of centrilobular nodules. A transbronchial biopsy shows an interstitial alveolar infiltrate of plasma cells, lymphocytes. There are also several loose noncaseating granulomas. All cultures are negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) is a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction caused by exposure to antigens.
  • It can present acutely or subacutely with symptoms like shortness of breath, cough, and fever.
  • Chronic HP may lead to severe symptoms, clubbing, and lung complications.
  • Diagnosis involves tests for inflammation markers and imaging (CT scan).
  • Treatment includes removing the patient from antigen exposure and using glucocorticoids if necessary.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2160

choices.text: Admit to an antenatal unit for bed rest and betamethasone.
Admit to an antenatal unit for bed rest and blood transfusion.

questions.text: A 33-year-old G1P0 woman at 29 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department complaining of 2 hours of vaginal bleeding. The bleeding recently stopped, but she was diagnosed earlier with placenta previa by ultrasound. She denies any abdominal pain, cramping, or contractions associated with the bleeding. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg, pulse is 75/min, and respiratory rate is 13/min. She reports she is Rh-positive, her hemoglobin is 11.1 g/dL, and coagulation tests, fibrinogen, and D-dimer levels are all normal. On examination her gravid abdomen is nontender. Foetal heart monitoring is reassuring, with a heart rate of 155/min, variable accelerations, and no decelerations. Two large-bore peripheral intravenous lines are inserted and two units of blood are typed and crossed. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
G1P0 woman at 29 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department complaining of 2 hours of vaginal bleeding, the bleeding recently stopped, her vitals are stable (temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg, pulse is 75/min, and respiratory rate is 13/min), FHS are present and reassuring i.e., there is no foetal distress.

All this means we will manage this patient expectantly and there is no need to immediately terminate her pregnancy, ruling out options c and d

  • So now we have to choose between option:
    • Admit to an antenatal unit for bed rest and betamethasone. And option
    • Admit to an antenatal unit for bed rest and blood transfusion.
  • The patient's Hb is 11.1, there is no need for immediate blood transfusion (ruling out option b), just crossmatch and arrange blood and give betamethasone for hastening lung maturity.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, Page no 248, 249

questions.text:
Identify the position:
'The head end of the table is tilted down on an incline with the patient's knees slightly flexed.
This is often used in pelvic procedures and when resuscitating a patient in shock'
questions.solution:
• Rose's position: slight neck extension for head and neck surgery.
  • Shoulder and arm extended: to assist in axillary and breast surgery.
  • Trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted down on an incline with the patient's knees slightly flexed. This is often used in pelvic procedures and when resuscitating a patient in shock
  • Reverse Trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted up, thereby placing the head higher than the feet.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 94, 95

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with itchy tense bullae over the limbs, the roof of the bulla collapsed after a few days. A clinical image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis for the 65-year-old man with itchy tense bullae over the limbs is Bullous Pemphigoid. It is characterized by tense bullae with an erythematous base, occurring in older age groups. The Tzanck smear is negative, and histologically, it shows a subepidermal split at the dermoepidermal junction (DEJ) containing eosinophils. Other immunobullous disorders have different clinical and histological features.

Reference: Rook′s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no: 50.1-50.22,50.52-50.55

choices.text: The commonest and most efficient vector is Xenopsylla cheopis
A blocked flea is one which is unable to feed because of enormous gut bacillary proliferation
A partially blocked flea is more dangerous than a completely blocked flea
The total flea index is more significant than the Cheopis index

questions.text: Regarding flea transmission in plague, all are true except:
questions.solution:
The Cheopis index is more significant and a value greater than 1 indicates potential explosiveness.

The commonest and the most efficient vector of plague is the rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis, but other fleas may also transmit the infection, e.g., X. astia, X. brasiliensis and Pulex irritans (human flea).

A flea may ingest upto 0.5 cu.mm of blood which may contain as many as 5,000 plague bacilli. The bacilli multiply enormously in the gut of the rat flea and may block the proventriculus so that no food can pass through. Such a flea is called a "blocked flea". A blocked flea eventually faces starvation and death because it is unable to obtain a blood meal. It makes frantic efforts to bite and suck blood over and over again; and in so doing, it inoculates (regurgitates) plague bacilli into the bite wound each time it bites. A blocked flea, therefore, becomes an efficient transmitter of plague.

A partially blocked flea can live longer and hence is considered more dangerous.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page no 320-321

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities is commonly seen in a fetus with congenital CMV infection:
questions.solution:
Manifestation of congenital CMV infection.

-Still birth

-Microcephaly

-Chorioretinitis

-Deafness

-Hemolytic anemia (Blood dyscrasias simply stands for any hematological disorder)

-Pneumonitis

-Thrombocytopenia with petechiae and purpura

Note: CMV never leads to heart defects in the foetus.

  • IUGR
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Icterus
  • Mental retardation
  • Have intracranial calcifications

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, Page no 300

questions.text: Match List I with List II and select the correct answer using the code given below the lists.
questions.solution:
Bagassosis - Bagassosis is a type of Hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by the inhalation of Sugarcane dust.

Byssinosis - Byssinosis is a type of Hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by the inhalation of Cotton dust.

Farmer's Lung - Farmer's Lung is a type of Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis caused by the inhalation of moldy hay.

Woodworker's Lung - Woodworker's Lung is a type of Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis caused by the inhalation of dust from Oak, Cedar, or Pine wood.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2160

choices.text: Arises as a result of reperfusion
Acute kidney injury and renal failure from myoglobinuria is a complication

questions.text: All are true about Crush syndrome except
questions.solution:
Crush Syndrome arises as a result of reperfusion. It occurs when a crush injury causes muscle tissue damage, and when the pressure is released, the damaged tissue undergoes reperfusion, leading to the release of harmful substances into the bloodstream.

Acute kidney injury and renal failure from myoglobinuria are complications of Crush Syndrome. Crushed muscles release myoglobin, which can cause kidney damage when it accumulates in the renal tubules, leading to acute kidney injury and potentially renal failure.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 459

questions.text: A female student presented with urticaria following intake of seafood. She wants a non-sedative drug since this is her exam time. Which is preferred antihistamine for this patient?
questions.solution:
The preferred antihistamine for the female student with urticaria following seafood intake, who wants a non-sedative drug during her exam time, is Fexofenadine.

Fexofenadine is a second-generation H-1 antihistamine, which does not easily cross the blood-brain barrier into the central nervous system (CNS), making it non-sedative. In contrast, first-generation H-1 antihistamines like Hydroxyzine, Promethazine, and Chlorphenamine can cause sedative side effects due to their ability to enter the CNS.

Reference: Rook′s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 46.4-6, 42.11, 42.5, 46.1-46.4, 46.9, 128.2, 128.75

questions.text: What is given by the number of deaths of children aged 1-4 years during a year per 1000 children in the same age group at the middle of the year?
questions.solution:
Child death rate is the number of deaths of children aged 1-4 years per 1000 children in the same age group in a given year. It thus excludes infant mortality.

Under-5 mortality rate is also called the child mortality rate. UNICEF defines this as the "annual number of deaths of children under 5 years, expressed as a rate per 1000 live births." More specifically, it measures the probability of dying between birth and exactly 5 years of age. It includes infant mortality.

A child survival rate per 1000 births can be simply calculated by subtracting the Under-5 mortality rate from 1000. Dividing this figure by ten shows the percentage of those who survive to the age of 5 years.

Child survival rate = (1000 - under-5 mortality rate) / 10

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page no 626, 627 and 630

questions.text: A 2-year-old child comes with complaints of coughing and high-grade fever for 2 days. His chest X ray is suggestive of pneumonia. At this age, which of the following is the most common bacterial cause of pneumonia?
questions.solution:
• Most common viral cause of pneumonia in children: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)
  • Most common bacterial cause of pneumonia in children: Streptococcus pneumoniae

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, Page no 2088

choices.text: Ulcer adjacent to a Meckel's diverticulum

questions.text: A 4 years old boy presenting with a haemoglobin of 40 g /l will most likely
questions.solution:
A 4-year-old boy presenting with a haemoglobin level of 40 g/l (4.0 g/dl) is likely to have significant gastrointestinal bleeding. In children, one of the common causes of gastrointestinal bleeding is a Meckel's diverticulum. Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital abnormality, and when it presents with ulceration or bleeding, it can lead to severe anaemia.

The other options, such as intussusception, peptic ulcer, and anal fissure, are less likely to cause such severe anaemia in a 4-year-old child.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 261

questions.text: A young lady presented with a lacy lesion in the oral cavity and her proximal nail fold extended onto the nail bed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A young lady with a lacy lesion in the oral cavity and her proximal nail fold extending onto the nail bed is likely to have Lichen planus.

Oral lichen planus presents as painless white streaks in a lacy or fern-like pattern on the oral mucosa. The nail change described, pterygium, is a classic finding associated with Lichen planus.

Candidiasis is a fungal infection characterized by white spots resembling curdled milk or cottage cheese.

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune disease with oral erosions and vesiculobullous lesions on the skin.

Psoriasis is a chronic skin condition that presents with raised, red, and scaly patches on the skin, but it does not typically involve the oral cavity or nails in the manner described in the case.

Reference: Rook′s Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition - Page no 37.1, 37.12, 37.16, 25.33

choices.text: It is a rapid and non- invasive method for assessing body fat.
The measurement may be taken at all the four sites - mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions.
A major advantage is its excellent repeatability.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the measurement of skinfold thickness testing?
questions.solution:
The main drawback of skinfold measurements is their poor repeatability. The other statements are true. The sum of the measurements at the four sites should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page no 429

questions.text: A female having 6 weeks amenorrhea presents with ovarian cyst. The proper management is:
questions.solution:
Most common ovarian tumor in pregnancy is benign cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst).

MC complication of ovarian tumors in pregnancy is torsion (M/C time of torsion-8-10 weeks or early puerperium). MC ovarian tumor to undergo torsion in pregnancy dermoid cyst.

Management of ovarian cyst during pregnancy

  • In case of complications - remove the tumor irrespective of gestational age.
  • During labour, if it leads to obstruction-do cesarean section and simultaneously remove the tumour.
  • During puerperium-Remove the tumor as early as possible.
  • M/C malignancies of ovaries seen in pregnancy.

Germ cell tumors > sex cord stromal tumors > low malignant potential tumors > epithelial tumors.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, Page no 310

questions.text: Which subtype of AML has the best prognosis among the following?
questions.solution:
• Acute promyeloblastic leukemia also known as M-3 associated with t(15:17) is very responsive to retinoic acid combined with anthracyclines.
  • 7 (acute megakaryocytic leukemia) mostly seen in down syndrome.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, Page no 2442)

choices.text: Bladder irrigation or instillation of normal saline antiseptic or antibiotic

questions.text: Which of the following techniques has not been proven effective for the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs)?
questions.solution:
Proven effective measures:

  1. Limit duration of catheter
  2. Aseptic technique at insertion
  3. Maintain closed drainage:
    1. Antiseptic added to drainage bag
    2. Antimicrobial-coated catheter
    3. Daily antiseptic perineal! Cleaning

Proven not effective:

  1. Systemic antibiotic prophylaxis
  2. Bladder irrigation or instillation of normal saline antiseptic or antibiotic

questions.text: A 40 years old female presented with shortening of the digits in her hands. She had positive Raynaud's phenomenon. 8 months back she had noticed puffiness of her fingers and face. ANA was positive with Nucleolar pattern on IF. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is an autoimmune connective tissue disease that affects the skin and various internal organs. It is classified into two main subtypes: Limited (Crest Syndrome) and Diffuse Systemic sclerosis. The presence of puffiness and diffuse skin involvement suggests the diagnosis of Diffuse SSc (Option B).

The Limited form, characterized by skin involvement restricted to the hands, face, and forearms, is less likely in this case.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2773,2783

questions.text: 'Amoeboma' arising in the large bowel, most commonly seen in the
questions.solution:
This is a chronic granuloma arising in the large bowel, most commonly seen in the caecum. It is prone to occur in long- standing amoebic infection that has been treated intermittently with drugs without completion of a full course, a situation that arises from indiscriminate self-medication, particularly in resource-poor countries. Hence this is more often seen in such countries.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 67

choices.text: Pregnancy continuing beyond expected date of delivery
Pregnancy continuing beyond 2 weeks of expected date of delivery

questions.text: Postdate pregnancy is defined as:
questions.solution:
Pregnancy continuing beyond 2 weeks of the expected date of delivery (> 294 days) is called postmaturity or post-term pregnancy.

Reference: D C Dutta's textbook of obstetrics, 8th edition, chapter 22, page number 87

questions.text: All are the important anatomical relations to the submandibular gland except
questions.solution:
The submandibular gland is a major salivary gland located in the submandibular triangle of the neck. It has several important anatomical relations:

  • Lingual nerve: The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3), runs close to the submandibular gland.
  • Hypoglossal nerve: The hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII) passes deep to the submandibular gland.
  • Anterior facial vein: The anterior facial vein drains into the facial vein, and it lies superficial to the submandibular gland.

Zygomatic branch of the facial nerve is not related to the submandibular gland. The zygomatic branch of the facial nerve innervates the zygomaticus major and zygomaticus minor muscles, which are muscles of facial expression in the cheek region.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 843

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of failure of vasectomy?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of failure of vasectomy is due to the mistaken identification of the vas. That is, instead of the vas, some other structure in the spermatic cord such as a thrombosed vein or thickened lymphatic has been taken. Histological confirmation has, therefore, been recommended on all vasectomy specimens by some authors in developed countries. In developing countries, histological confirmation is ruled out because of lack of facilities for such an examination. A simpler method has been recommended, that is, microscopic examination of a smear prepared by gentle squeezing of the vas on a glass slide and staining with Wright's stain. The vas can be identified by the presence of columnar epithelial cells that line the lumen of the vas.

In some cases, failure may be due to spontaneous recanalisation of vas. Sometimes there may be more than one vas on one side. Pregnancy could also result from sexual intercourse before the disappearance of sperms from the reproductive tract.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page no 560

questions.text: Which of the following disorders will cause an increase in functional residual capacity?
questions.solution:
• Functional residual capacity (FRC) refers to the volume of air that remains in the lung at end expiration following a normal tidal respiration.
  • This volume of air represents the point at which the outward recoil of the chest wall is in equilibrium with the inward elastic recoil of the lungs.
  • In emphysema, the elastic recoil of the lungs is reduced (lung compliance is higher), so the FRC will be higher.
  • All of the other conditions will either reduce the outward recoil of the chest wall (abdominal muscle paralysis, diaphragmatic weakness, and obesity), or increase the elastic recoil of the lungs (pulmonary fibrosis), which would lead to a reduction in the FRC.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2134

questions.text: An infant presents with the condition as shown below after a pharyngeal infection. The shown condition is:
questions.solution:
The shown condition is Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It usually follows a pharyngeal infection in neonates and infants. The condition presents with fever, irritability, and skin tenderness, followed by a widespread erythematous eruption that rapidly progresses to superficial blister formation (Nikolsky positive). Mucosal involvement is absent. Treatment involves hospitalization and i/v antibiotics, typically a penicillinase-resistant anti-staphylococcal antibiotic such as flucloxacillin.

Reference: Rook′s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, page no 26.27 - 26.29

choices.text: A country's surveillance system needs to be sensitive enough to detect at least one case of AFP for every 1 million children under 15, even in the absence of polio.
All children with acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) should be reported and tested for wild poliovirus within 72 hours of onset.
Stool specimens have to be sealed in containers and stored immediately inside a refrigerator or packed between frozen ice packs at-20°C.
Specimens should arrive at the laboratory within 72 hours of collection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about poliomyelitis surveillance?
questions.solution:
A country's surveillance system needs to be sensitive enough to detect at least one case of AFP for every 100,000 (not 1 million) children under 15, even in the absence of polio (option A).

All children with acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) should be reported and tested for wild poliovirus within 48 (not 72) hours of onset. Stool specimens have to be sealed in containers and stored immediately inside a refrigerator or packed between frozen ice packs at-4-8 (not -20) ° C.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page no 223

questions.text: A lady presented with carcinoma endometrium involving >50% of myometrium extending to vagina and positive peritoneal cytology but no involvements of para-aortic and pre aortic nodes. What is the stage of disease?
questions.solution:
50% myometrial invasion means stage IC, positive peritoneal cytology puts it in stage III A. Vaginal metastasis means stage III B cancer and since this is the highest stage.

Therefore, this patient has endometrial cancer belonging to stage III B.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 15th Edition, Page no 420

choices.text: It is self-limiting, no treatment required

questions.text: A 48 years old male patient is diagnosed with hypersensitivity pneumonitis. What is the true statement regarding treatment of Acute hypersensitivity pneumonitis?
questions.solution:
• Because acute HP is generally a self-limited disease after a discreet exposure to an offending antigen, pharmacologic therapy is generally not necessary.
  • However, in so-called subacute and chronic forms of the disease, there is a role for glucocorticoid therapy. In patients with particularly severe symptoms as a result of subacute HP, antigen avoidance may be insufficient after establishing the diagnosis. Although glucocorticoids do not change the long-term outcome in these patients, they can accelerate the resolution of symptoms.
  • While there is significant variability in the approach to glucocorticoid therapy by individual clinicians, prednisone therapy can be initiated at 0.5-1 mg/kg of ideal body weight per day (not to exceed 60 mg/d or alternative glucocorticoid equivalent) over a duration of 1-2 weeks, followed by a taper over the next 2-6 weeks.
  • In chronic HP, a similar trial of corticosteroids may be, although a variable component of fibrotic disease may be irreversible. In advanced cases of chronic HP with extensive lung fibrosis, lung transplantation may be necessary.
  • Immunosuppressants had no role in hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2162

questions.text: Which of the following is the example of hydrocephalus due to excessive CSF production?
questions.solution:
Hydrocephalus is a condition characterized by the accumulation of excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the ventricles of the brain. It can occur due to various reasons, including obstruction of CSF flow, impaired absorption of CSF, or excessive production of CSF.

Choroid plexus papilloma is an example of hydrocephalus due to excessive CSF production. Choroid plexus papilloma is a rare, benign tumor that originates from the choroid plexus in the ventricles of the brain. This tumor can cause an overproduction of CSF, leading to hydrocephalus.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 703

choices.text: External fixation and percutaneous screw reduction of the fracture
Lag screw fixation followed by locking plate application

questions.text: A 68-year-old healthy active male presents after falling and sustaining an injury to his right knee. His medical history is significant only for osteoporosis. Radiographs and representative CT scan images are shown below. What is the most appropriate treatment method for this patient's injury?
questions.solution:
The injury shown in Figures represents a comminuted metaphyseal distal femur fracture with a sagittally oriented intra-articular split in osteoporotic bone. Because of the intra-articular nature of this injury, the best fixation construct for treatment of this fracture in an otherwise healthy and active patient is lag screw fixation followed by locked plate application.

In osteoporotic patients, plating with locked screws improve the biology and the mechanics of internal fixation. Furthermore, when this fixation method is used as an 'internal ex fix' (bridging construct) it may stimulate early callus formation because of the inherent flexibility of the construct.

Reference: Rockwood and green fracture in adults, 9th Edition, Page no 3917

questions.text: Which of the following glands contribute to mucus production in the olfactory neuroepithelium?
questions.solution:
The glands within the lamina propria were first described by Todd and Bowman in 1847. Named Bowman's glands by von Kölliker in 1858, these glands provide a microenvironment in which optimal odorant absorption is enhanced. There are no Schneiderian glands, although the nasal mucous membrane is sometimes termed the Schneiderian membrane. Ebner's glands secrete mucus around the circumvallate papillae, whereas Magendie's glands are fictitious. Ciliary glands are related to the hair follicles of the eyelashes.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 16th edition, page no 561

questions.text: Most common benign cardiac mass in adults is
questions.solution:
Atrial myxoma: This is the most common benign cardiac mass in adults. Myxomas are neoplasms of endocardial origin, often appearing as pedunculated masses most commonly seen in the left (75%) or the right (20%) atria. They are rarely found in the ventricles.

Myxomas are associated with a congenital disorder (Carney complex) in 5% of cases. They usually present with symptoms related to blood flow obstruction through heart valves or systemic embolisation. Treatment is by surgical excision and recurrence rates are usually <5%

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 972

questions.text: Which of the following is a known effect of dengue to a foetus, if mother is affected:
questions.solution:
Dengue fever in pregnancy

Material risks:

  1. Associated with high maternal mortality
  2. Deranged liver functions may mimic HELLP syndrome.

Fetal Risks:

  • No evidence of teratogenicity, abortion or IUGR following dengue infection during pregnancy
  • Vertical transmission is present.
  • Newborn presents with fever, hepatomegaly and thrombocytopenia. In grave infection a newborn may show coagulopathy.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, page no 313-314

questions.text: A 40 years old male alcoholic presents with features of fever and productive cough that increases with postural changes. CXR of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The CXR shows an air fluid level diagnostic of lung abscess.
  • The history of alcoholism predisposes to suppression of the protective airway reflexes under the influence of alcohol.
  • Hence the anaerobic organism in the saliva can enter the airway and can cause development of suppurative lung abscess.
  • The main clinical pointer in the question indicating presence of lung abscess is postural change in purulent sputum.
  • The best antibiotic to treat anaerobic lung abscess is Clindamycin.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1021

questions.text: The extent of Spinal cord injury is defined by American spinal injury association (ASIA) impairment scale (modified from Frankel classification) type B is
questions.solution:
The extent of spinal cord injury is defined by the American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) Impairment Scale (modified from the Frankel classification):

  • A: complete spinal cord injury;
  • B: sensation present, motor absent;
  • C: sensation present, motor present but not useful (MRC grade <3/5);
  • D: sensation present, motor useful (MRC grade ≥3/5);
  • E: normal function.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 391

choices.text: Antecedent history of febrile illness is common
Occurs due to overactive immune reaction

questions.text: An otherwise well 6 years old girl comes to you with complaints of rashes all over the body as follows. The lesions have been increasing every day since the last 3 days. CBC shows a platelet count of 20,000. She has no other complaints or any bleeding from other sites. Which of the following statements about the condition is false?
questions.solution:
• Otherwise healthy children with low platelet count and bruises/purple dots are significant for Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.
  • Generally, there is an antecedent history of febrile illness, 1-4 weeks before.
  • There is production of autoantibodies against the antigens on the platelets leading to thrombocytopenia.
  • Treatment options for severe ITP include Prednisolone, IVIG, Anti-D.
  • The antiplatelet antibodies bind to the transfused platelets also; hence platelet transfusion is contraindicated unless there is very severe bleeding.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, Page no 2403

questions.text: Under the National AIDS Control Programme (NACP), how would you classify a district having less than 1 % ANC/PTCT prevalence in all the sites during last 3 years but associated with more than 5 % prevalence in any HRG group (STD/CSW/MSM/IDU)?
questions.solution:
More than 1 % ANC/PTCT prevalence in the district at any time in any of the sites in the last 3 years. - Category A

Less than 1 % ANC/PTCT prevalence in all the sites during last 3 years associated with more than 5 % prevalence in any HRG group (STD/CSW/MSM/IDU) - Category B

Less than 1 % in ANC prevalence in all sites during the last 3 years with less than 5% in all STD clinic attendees or any HRG with known hot spots (Migrants, truckers, large aggregation of factory workers, tourists etc.) - Category C

Less than 1 % in ANC prevalence in a ll sites during last 3 years with less than 5% in all STD clinic attendees or any HRG OR, poor HIV data with no known hot spots - Category D

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page no 466

questions.text: A 25 years old female patient had an episodic breathlessness, cough without expectoration after exposure to dust and in winter season. On examination B/L wheeze present. She diagnosed as Bronchial asthma on PFT. What is the hallmark feature of Bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Airway Hyperresponsiveness

  • Airway hyperresponsiveness is a hallmark of asthma.
  • It is defined as an acute narrowing response of the airways in reaction to agents that do not elicit airway responses in non-affected individuals or an excess narrowing response to inhaled agents as compared to that which would occur in non-affected individuals.
  • A component of the hyperresponsiveness occurs at the level of the airway smooth muscle itself as demonstrated by hyperresponsiveness to direct smooth-muscle-acting agents such as histamine or methacholine. In patients, the apparent hyperresponsiveness is due to indirect activation of airway narrowing mechanisms as a result of stimulation of inflammatory cells (which release direct bronchoconstrictors and mediators that cause airway oedema and/ or mucus secretion) and/ or stimulation of sensory nerves that can act on the smooth muscle or inflammatory cells.
  • In asthma, airway wall thickness is associated with disease severity and duration. This thickening, which may result from a combination of smooth-muscle hypertrophy and hyperplasia, subepithelial collagen deposition, airway oedema, and mucosal inflammation, can result in a tendency for the airway to narrow disproportionately in response to stimuli that elicit increased airway muscle tension.
  • A major therapeutic objective in asthma is to decrease the degree of airway hyperresponsiveness.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2149

questions.text: All are the medical exclusions to day surgery except
questions.solution:
Day surgery is a form of outpatient surgery where patients are discharged on the same day after their procedure. Medical exclusions for day surgery typically include patients with significant medical conditions or comorbidities that require close monitoring and post-operative care.

Options B, C, and D are medical exclusions to day surgery as they involve patients with higher ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists) classification, poorly controlled abnormalities, or comorbidities.

However, option A (stable ASA 3) is not a medical exclusion and may be considered for day surgery in some cases depending on the specific patient and procedure.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 300

questions.text: How will you manage a case of OCD?
questions.solution:
CBT plus SSRI are the treatment of choice and better than CBT/SSRI used individually.

Clomipramine is not the first choice agent because of associated side effects.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th Edition, page no 1356

questions.text: A 6 weeks old child is given the first dose of the pentavalent vaccine at a primary health centre (PHC). 30 minutes later, the infant starts crying inconsolably, and this goes on for 4 hours. How would you classify this adverse event following immunization (AEFI)?
questions.solution:
This is an example of a vaccine product-related reaction. It is an AEFI that is caused or precipitated by a vaccine due to one or more of the inherent properties of the vaccine product, in this case likely due to the pertussis component.

A vaccine quality defect-related reaction (option A) is an AEFI that is caused or precipitated by a vaccine that is due to one or more quality defects of the vaccine product, including its administration device as provided by the manufacturer.

An immunization anxiety-related reaction (option C) is an AEFI arising from anxiety about the immunization. This usually manifests as intense crying before vaccine administration or as vasovagal syncope.

A coincidental event (option D) is an AEFI that is caused by something other than the vaccine product, immunization error or immunization anxiety; for example, a child developing a cough after oral polio vaccine (OPV) administration but tests positive for COVID-19.

Other types of AEFI: An immunization error-related reaction (formerly "programme error") is an AEFI that is caused by inappropriate vaccine handling, prescribing or administration and thus by its nature is preventable; for example, contamination of measles-containing vaccine (MCV) vials with Staphylococcus aureus leading to toxic shock syndrome in vaccine recipients.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page no 122

questions.text: 19-year-old unmarried girl came to OPD with a cystic lesion over labia. Cyst is fluctuant and non-tender. It is caused by:
questions.solution:
Bartholin's cyst is the most common cyst of the vulva, resulting from the accumulation of secretions from Bartholin's gland. It can develop in the duct or the gland and is usually caused by obstruction, often due to fibrosis from infection or trauma. While gonococcus was previously thought to be the main cause, now it is known that almost any organism can be responsible. The cyst presents as a unilateral, non-tender, fluctuant swelling near the junction of the anterior 2/3rd with the posterior 1/3rd of the labium majus. Treatment of choice is Marsupialization, which is preferred over traditional excision operations.

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 1st edition, Page no 96

questions.text: Which is the following is the extra axial brain tumour?
questions.solution:
An extra-axial brain tumor is a tumor that arises from structures outside of the brain parenchyma (the brain tissue itself). Meningioma is an example of an extra-axial brain tumor as it originates from the meninges, which are the membranes that cover and protect the brain and spinal cord.

The other options, pineal tumors, medulloblastoma, and astrocytoma, are all intracranial tumors that arise from brain tissue (intra-axial) rather than from structures outside the brain (extra-axial).

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 713

questions.text: Which of the following hepatitis viruses is associated with a significantly higher mortality rate in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Pregnant women are at greater risk of obstetrical complications and mortality from hepatitis E, which can induce a mortality rate of 20% among pregnant women in their third trimester.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page no 242

choices.text: BCR-ABL1 of Ph-like ALL has increasing frequency with age
Patients with Down syndrome are at increased risk of developing acute myelogenous leukaemia (AML) but not ALL
Lumbar puncture is an essential diagnostic measure
Most adult ALLs are of T-cell origin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding acute lymphoblastic lymphoma (ALL) is true?
questions.solution:
• In acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the malignant clone arises from hematopoietic progenitors in the bone marrow or lymphatic system resulting in an increase of immature nonfunctioning leukemic cells. Infiltration of bone marrow leads to anaemia, granulocytopenia, and thrombocytopenia with the clinical manifestations of fatigue, weakness, infection, and haemorrhages.
  • Patients with some rare congenital chromosomal abnormalities have a higher risk of development of acute leukaemia; e.g., Klinefelter syndrome, Fanconi anaemia, Bloom syndrome, ataxia telangiectasia, and neurofibromatosis. There is a 20-fold increased incidence of leukemia in patients with Down syndrome, in whom ALL is increased in childhood and acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) at an older age.
  • Genetic predisposition may play a part in acute leukemia even, when not associated with another inherited disease, as the identical twin of a leukemic child has a fivefold risk of developing acute leukemia.
  • The examination of the cerebrospinal fluid is an essential routine diagnostic measure for ALL due to the high risk of central nervous system (CNS) involvement to help guide therapy.
  • More than 70% of adult ALLs are of B-cell origin, and the most frequent immunological subtype, common ALL, is characterized by the presence of ALL antigen, a glycoprotein (gp100/ CD10).
  • Approximately 25% of adult ALLs belong to the T-cell lineage. BCR-ABL1-like ALL is characterized by genetic lesions similar to Ph+ ALL, associated with IKZF1 deletion, CLRF2 overexpression, and tyrosine kinase activating rearrangements involving ABL1, JAK2, PDGFRB, and several others. The frequency is 10% in children and 25-30% in young adults, but does not increase further with age.
  • Treatment may be directed at the underlying genetic pattern with BCR-ABL inhibitors (e.g., dasatinib) or JAK2 inhibitors (e.g., ruxolitinib).

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 829

questions.text: Pap smear of 46 years female shows CIN grade III. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
• Pap smear is only a screening test. To confirm we need to do a biopsy.
  • In all visible lesions punch biopsy should be done
  • In the case of invisible lesions, colposcopic directed biopsy is the gold standard.

Thus, in this case since it is not mentioned growth is visible so we do colposcopy guided biopsy.

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 1st edition, Page no 628

questions.text: A baby born with a membrane around him at the time of birth. Which of the following condition is depicted?
questions.solution:
LI is an autosomal recessive disease. Infants with this condition are typically born with a tight, clear sheath covering their skin called a collodion membrane. This membrane usually dries and peels off during the first few weeks of life, and then it becomes obvious that affected babies have scaly skin, and eyelids and lips that are turned outward. People with lamellar ichthyosis typically have large, dark, plate-like scales covering their skin on most of their body. Infants with lamellar ichthyosis may develop infections, an excessive loss of fluids (dehydration), and respiratory problems.

Ichthyosis vulgaris is one of the most common inherited skin disorders. It may begin in early childhood. The condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

Recessive X-linked ichthyosis, also called steroid sulfatase (STS) deficiency, is an X-linked recessive ichthyosis caused by a defect in the STS gene. Preauricular accentuations, undescended testes occur in XLI.

Reference: Rook′s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 65.6

questions.text: Identify the correct pair of disorders and its chromosomal anomalies
questions.solution:
Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome, also known as Monosomy X, is a genetic disorder that affects females. The chromosomal anomaly associated with Turner syndrome is 45X0, which means that affected individuals have only one X chromosome instead of the usual two (X chromosomes).

Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects males. The chromosomal anomaly associated with Klinefelter syndrome is 47XXY, which means that affected individuals have an extra X chromosome, resulting in a total of 47 chromosomes instead of the usual 46.

Down syndrome: Down syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects both males and females.

The chromosomal anomaly associated with Down syndrome is Trisomy 21, which means that affected individuals have three copies of chromosome 21 instead of the usual two (one from each parent), resulting in a total of 47 chromosomes.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3001

questions.text: A woman treated for infertility, presents with 6 weeks amenorrhea with urinary retention. The most likely etiology :
questions.solution:
The most likely etiology for a woman with 6-week amenorrhea and urinary retention is an impacted cervical fibroid. This condition can cause acute onset urinary retention, especially before menstruation or during early pregnancy when the fibroid becomes enlarged and impacts the pouch of Douglas. Retroverted gravid uterus and pelvic hematocoele are less likely based on the clinical presentation. Carcinoma cervix is not a common cause of urinary retention at 6 weeks of amenorrhea.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 155

questions.text: Which of the following is measured to detect recurrence in sacrococcygeal teratoma
questions.solution:
Sacrococcygeal teratoma: These germ cell tumours arise from the coccyx and are usually diagnosed antenatally. They may have internal and external components or both. Most are benign mature teratomas, but some contain immature embryonic elements. Complete excision is usually achieved in the prone position and must include removing the coccyx and reconstruction of the pelvic floor. If the intra-abdominal component is large or vascular, the median sacral artery can be ligated through the abdomen. Bladder and bowel function are assessed following the pelvic floor repair.

α-Fetoprotein levels are measured to detect recurrence.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 272

choices.text: When indicated, start 24-72 h after chemotherapy
Continue until absolute neutrophil count is 10,000/μL
Do not use concurrently with chemotherapy or radiation therapy
Dose G-CSF: 5 mg/kg per day intramuscular

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Granulocyte colony stimulating agent except?
questions.solution:
G-CSF is administered subcutaneously, not intramuscular. So, this statement is wrong.

Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) is a medication used to stimulate the production of white blood cells, particularly neutrophils, in patients undergoing chemotherapy or with certain medical conditions.

The dosing of G-CSF can vary depending on the specific product and indication, but 5 mg/kg per day intramuscular is not a standard dosing regimen for G-CSF.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 554

questions.text: Strawberry vagina is seen in:
questions.solution:
Trichomonas is spirochete infection. It is the most common non-viral STD. It occurs in alkaline pH.

Symptoms:

Profuse and offensive greenish vaginal discharge, Intense pruritus

Treatment: tab. Metronidazole 2 g single dose

questions.solution:
Pleomorphic adenoma- These are the most common benign salivary gland tumours. They can occur at all ages, but are most commonly seen between the third and sixth decade. The average age of presentation is 45 years and they are more frequently seen in women.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presented with acute respiratory failure during an episode of acute pneumonia and was thought to have developed adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Which of the following would support a diagnosis of ARDS?
questions.solution:
• ARDS is characterised by hypoxaemia, reduced lung compliance, pulmonary hypertension and pulmonary infiltrates on the chest X-ray. There is damage to the capillary and endothelial cell linings resulting in oedema and leakage of proteins and cells into the interstitial and alveolar spaces at normal pulmonary capillary hydrostatic pressures. Wedge pressure, unlike the high pressures seen with LVF and pulmonary oedema, is often normal.
  • Hypercapnia often a late feature of ARDS does not distinguish from any other cause of type 2 respiratory failure.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21th edition, Page no 2226

questions.text: A 48 years old postmenopausal female diagnosed with Brenner's tumor of ovary. True about Brenner tumor is:
questions.solution:
Brenner tumour is also called as Transitional cell tumour:

  • It is a rare epithelial neoplasm of ovary resembling fibroma.
  • It is an essentially benign tumour.
  • Tumour is generally seen in women around menopause and is generally unilateral.
  • Causes menopausal bleeding and Pseudo Meigs syndrome (ascites and hydrothorax).
  • Malignant change is very rare.
  • Histologically it shows walthard cell nests of transitional cells, cells have coffee bean nuclei, cut section is gritty.

questions.solution:
In the options given, obese patients suggest a difficult airway. There is increased adipose tissue resulting in increased neck circumference, limitation in neck movements, obscured bony landmarks. Large breasts or fat in the chest wall can cause difficult laryngoscopy and instrumentation.

questions.text: A 48 years old male patient with a known case of HTN and DM-2 had a complaint of acute onset right side weakness. In emergency, NCCT Brain Was done which was normal. What is the window period for thrombolysis of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Stroke is a common cause of neurologic critical illness. Hypertension must be managed carefully, because abrupt reductions in blood pressure may be associated with further brain ischemia and injury.
  • Acute ischemic stroke treated with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) has an improved neurologic outcome when treatment is given within 4.5 h of onset of symptoms, with likely increased benefit associated with earlier administration.
  • The mortality rate is not reduced when tPA is compared with placebo, despite the improved neurologic outcome. The risk of cerebral hemorrhage is significantly higher in patients given tPA. No benefit is seen when tPA therapy is given beyond 4.5 h after symptom onset.
  • Heparin has not been convincingly shown to improve outcomes in patients with acute ischemic stroke.
  • Decompressive craniectomy is a surgical procedure that relieves increased intracranial pressure in the setting of space-occupying brain lesions or brain swelling from stroke; available evidence suggests that this procedure may improve survival among select patients (e.g., ≤55 years)

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21th edition, Page number 2224

Prolonged serous otitis media usually longer than 2 months duration

questions.text: All are the indications of adenoidectomy except
questions.solution:
Adenoid tissue can be removed alone or in conjunction with a tonsillectomy. The indications for adenoidectomy are:

  • OSA associated with post nasal obstruction;
  • recurrent acute otitis media or prolonged serous otitis media, usually longer than 3 months duration;
  • recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • postnasal discharge
