questions.text: A manic episode is a distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive or irritable mood lasting for at least-
questions.solution:
A manic episode is a period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood lasting for at least 7 days. During this period, the individual may experience increased energy levels, decreased need for sleep, racing thoughts, impulsivity, and engaging in high-risk behaviours. Manic episodes are a hallmark feature of bipolar disorder and can significantly impact the person's functioning and daily life.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no 292-293

choices.text: It is a viral hemorrhagic fever
Restricted to certain districts in Karnataka
Monkeys serve as reservoirs for the disease

questions.text: All of the statements regarding Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) are true except:
questions.solution:
Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) is a febrile disease associated with haemorrhages caused by an arbovirus flavivirus and transmitted to man by bite of infective ticks.

The disease is now restricted to four districts (Shimoga, North Kannada, South Kannada and Chikamagaloor) in Karnataka State in India.

Small mammals, particularly rats and squirrels are the main reservoirs of the virus. Birds and bats are less important hosts. The monkeys are recognized as amplifying hosts for the virus. However, they are not effective maintenance hosts because most of them die from KFD infection.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page no 315

questions.text: Which is the recent oral direct thrombin inhibitor which can be used for prevention of stroke?
questions.solution:
Novel Oral Anticoagulants (NOACs) also known as direct oral anticoagulants are a new class of anticoagulants that include oral thrombin inhibitor (dabigatran) and oral factor Xa inhibitors like rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban. They are easier to use, achieve reliable anticoagulation, and do not require dosage adjustment based on blood tests. They have a lower risk of intracranial hemorrhage compared to warfarin and are used as alternatives to warfarin for patients who have atrial fibrillation.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 935

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with abdominal pain, distension, ascites and dyspnoea. Her CA 125 levels are elevated. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Primary ovarian neoplasms are most common in women aged 40-60 years, with the peak age incidence at 55-60 years. Ovarian malignancies present with vague symptoms like abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and irregular menses. Pelvic mass can cause urinary frequency or constipation.

Advanced stages show symptoms related to ascites, metastasis, abdominal distension, dyspn0ea, bloating, nausea, and anorexia. CA 125 levels are raised in ovarian cancer, along with the presence of a pelvic mass on physical examination.

A very high serum CA125 level (>200U/ml) in postmenopausal patients with an adnexal mass has a 96% positive predictive value for ovarian malignancy.

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 761-763

questions.text: MEN Type1 is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome consisting of tumours of all of the following except
questions.solution:
MEN type 1-associated hyperparathyroidism

MEN type 1 is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome consisting of tumours of the parathyroids, endocrine pancreas-duodenum and the pituitary (the three Ps). It occurs in approximately 1 per 30 000 individuals. It can also be associated with adrenal adenomas or carcinoma, foregut carcinoids and lipomas. Mutations, of which there are over 1000 identified in different families, occur in the MEN1 gene, which encodes the protein menin. Menin acts as a tumour suppressor. Patients typically present with young onset (20-30 years of age) of symptomatic hyperparathyroidism and over 95% of patients will have PHPT before the age of 40 years.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 882

questions.text: What is also referred to as '8th day disease'?
questions.solution:
The common cause of neonatal tetanus is infection of the umbilical stump after birth, the first symptom being seen about the 7th day. Therefore, tetanus is known as '8th day disease' in Punjab

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page no 340

questions.text: A cesarean section was done in the previous pregnancy. All of the following would be indications for elective cesarean section except:
questions.solution:
Factors favouring successful trial of labor: Transverse incision, Prior vaginal delivery, Appropriate counseling, Sufficient personnel and equipment, Teaching hospital, Spontaneous labor, Prior fetal malpresentation, 1 or 2 prior transverse incisions, Nonrecurrent indication, Current preterm pregnancy.

Factors increasing failure rate: Macrosomic fetus, Breech presentation, Multifetal pregnancy, Preeclampsia, EGA > 40 weeks, Low-vertical incision, Unknown incision, Labor induction, medical disease, Multiple prior cesarean deliveries, Education < 12 years, Short inter-delivery interval, Liability concerns.

High-risk factors for elective cesarean section: Classical or T incision in previous cesarean delivery, Prior uterine rupture, Patient refusal, Transfundal surgery, Obstetrical contraindication (e.g., placenta previa), Inadequate facilities.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 24th Edition, Page no 611

questions.text: Which of the following endocrinopathies can cause an elevated creatine kinase up to 10 times the upper limit of normal?
questions.solution:
• Endocrinopathies can cause weakness, but fatigue is more common than true weakness.
  • The serum creatine kinase (CK) level is often normal (except in hypothyroidism) and the muscle histology is characterized by atrophy rather than destruction of muscle fibers.
  • Nearly all endocrine myopathies respond to appropriate treatment. Patients with hypothyroidism have frequent muscle complaints, and about one-third have proximal muscle weakness. Muscle cramps, pain, and stiffness are common. Some patients have enlarged muscles.
  • Features of slow muscle contraction and relaxation occur in 25% of patients; the relaxation phase of muscle stretch reflexes is characteristically prolonged and best observed at the ankle or biceps brachii reflexes.
  • The serum CK level is often elevated (up to 10 times normal).
  • Electromyography is typically normal. Muscle biopsy shows no distinctive morphologic abnormalities.
  • In contrast, patients who are thyrotoxic commonly have proximal muscle weakness, but they rarely complain of myopathic symptoms.
  • Proximal muscle weakness, muscle wasting, and brisk muscle stretch reflexes are the main features of hyperparathyroidism.
  • In hypoparathyroidism, overt myopathy due to hypocalcaemia rarely occurs.
  • In primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome), neuromuscular complications are due to potassium depletion. The clinical picture is one of persistent muscle weakness.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3530

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about mifepristone?
questions.solution:
RU 486(Mifepristone) is a 19 nor steroid synthetic derivative of progesterone.

It has affinity for progesterone receptors and therefore blocks its actions. Route of administration.

Oral uses:

  • As post coital pill (600 mg given within 72 hrs of unprotected sex)
  • To induce abortion upto 7 weeks of amenorrhea along with misoprostol (medical abortion)
  • Ripening of cervix prior to prostaglandin induction of mid trimester abortion.
  • Management of ectopic pregnancy.
  • Cushing's syndrome, because of it's anti glucocorticoid acrtion.
  • Medical management of uterine fibroid.

Side effects:

  • Hedadache
  • GI upset
  • Adrenal failure
  • Teratogenicity (if medical methods of abortion fails with RU - 486, pregnancy should be terminated anyhow)

Reference- Shaw 15th edition, pg- 237, 246, 317

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about an ideal IUD candidate?
questions.solution:
The Planned Parenthood Federation of America (PPFA) has described the ideal IUD candidate as a woman:

  • who has borne at least one child.
  • has no history of pelvic disease.
  • has normal menstrual periods.
  • is willing to check the IUD tail.
  • has access to follow-up and treatment of potential problems, and
  • is in a monogamous relationship.

The federation does not, however, rule out women who do not conform to this profile.

An important finding that has recently emerged is that the IUD is not a method of first choice for nulliparous women. They have more problems with IUD such as expulsions, low abdominal pain and pelvic infection, than other women.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page no 548

choices.text: Operative time longer than the expected duration for similar procedure (75th percentile)

questions.text: The National Nosocomial Infections Surveillance (NNIS) score is commonly used to predict surgical site infections (SSIs). It was established in recognition of the effectiveness of infection surveillance in reducing SSIs. The NNIS score stratified surgical wound infection rates by risk factors. All are the risk factors except
questions.solution:
The National Nosocomial Infections Surveillance (NNIS) score is commonly used to predict surgical site infections (SSIs). It was established in recognition of the effectiveness of infection surveillance in reducing SSIs. The NNIS score stratified surgical wound infection rates by risk factors.

This risk index score ranges from 0 (lowest SSI risk) to 3 (highest SSI risk) with a point allocated for the presence of each of the following risk factors:

1) contaminated or dirty wound;

2) American Society of Anesthesiologists score ≥3;

3) Operative time longer than the expected duration for simi- lar procedures (>75th percentile).

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 29

questions.text: A 36 years old female has a history of hypothyroidism and polycystic ovarian syndrome. She has had two successful pregnancies that were both complicated by gestational hypertension. She also has a family history of stroke in her paternal grandmother and colon cancer in her mother. Which of the following puts her at increased risk for developing type 2 diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
• Women are more sensitive to insulin than are men. Despite this, the prevalence of type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) is similar in men and women.
  • There is a sex difference in the relationship between endogenous androgen levels and DM risk. Higher bioavailable testosterone levels are associated with increased risk in women, whereas lower bioavailable testosterone levels are associated with increased risk in men.
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome, preeclampsia, pregnancy-associated hypertension, and gestational DM-common conditions in pre-menopausal women-are associated with a significantly increased risk for type 2 DM.
  • Among individuals with DM, women have a greater risk for myocardial infarction than do men.
  • Women with DM have a sixfold greater risk of dying of cerebrovascular disease (CVD) compared with women without DM.
  • Pre-menopausal women with DM lose the cardioprotective effect of female sex and have rates of CVD identical to those in males.
  • These women have impaired endothelial function and reduced coronary vasodilatory responses, which may predispose to cardiovascular complications.
  • Women with DM are more likely to have left ventricular hypertrophy. Women with DM receive less aggressive treatment for modifiable CVD risk factors than men with DM.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3066

questions.text: A patient treated for infertility with clomiphene citrate presents with sudden onset of abdominal pain and distension with ascites, the probable cause is:
questions.solution:
Effects of clomiphene:

  • Multiple pregnancy (6-8%) < 10%
  • Ovarian cysts
  • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (<1%)

Anti Estrogenic side effects

  • Hot Flashes, osteoporosis
  • Long Term use-ovarian malignancy

Note: No congenital malformation seen

  • Most common effects are hot flushes and ovarian cyst formation.

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 223, 390, 400, 454-457, 766

questions.text: Most common histological subtype of bladder cancer is
questions.solution:
The most common histological subtype of bladder cancer is transitional cell carcinoma (also known as urothelial carcinoma). Transitional cell carcinoma arises from the urothelial lining of the bladder and accounts for the majority of bladder cancer cases (approximately 90-95%). Adenocarcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and sarcoma are less common subtypes of bladder cancer.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1516

questions.text: A 27 years old male presents with back pain which is more in the morning and decreases in the evening. It is also relieved by bathing in warm water. What do you expect from this patient?
questions.solution:
• The clinical feature of young male waking up to a low backache worse in morning and relieved on physical movement by evening suggestive of diagnosis of ankylosing Spondylitis.
  • These patients in future can develop costochondritis leading to restriction in chest expansion.
  • The most specific findings involve loss of spinal mobility, with limitation of anterior and lateral flexion and of chest expansion.
  • Ankylosing spondylosis presents with bone marrow oedema.
  • RA is more common in middle aged women with peripheral polyarthritis involving the small joint in hand symmetrically.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2792

choices.text: Reiter's disease is an autoimmune disease characterised by the triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis and polyarthritis
Common triggers include chlamydial urethritis, less commonly gonococcal urethritis and diarrhoea secondary to Salmonella, Shigella or Campylobacter
The conjunctivitis (present in around 50%) and arthritis typically occur 1-3 months after the primary infection

questions.text: All are true about Reiter's disease except
questions.solution:
Reiter's disease (synonym: sexually acquired reactive arthritis)

Reiter's disease is an autoimmune disease characterised by the triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis and polyarthritis.

Common triggers include chlamydial urethritis, less commonly gonococcal urethritis and diarrhoea secondary to Salmonella, Shigella or Campylobacter.

It is an HLA-B27-associated condition.

The conjunctivitis (present in around 50%) and arthritis typically occur 1-3 weeks after the primary infection. Diagnosis is made on clinical grounds and treatment is largely symptomatic, although antibiotic treatment of the precipitating infection is important.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1554

questions.solution:
Cohort studies are more expensive than case-control studies.

  • CA 125 is associated with Ovarian cancer.
  • Neuron-Specific Enolase is associated with Small Cell Carcinoma of the Lung (Small cell Ca. Lung).

questions.text: 9 years old girl diagnosed with Idiopathic central precocious puberty. Treatment of idiopathic central precocious puberty is:
questions.solution:
DOC for managing central precocious puberty is GnRH analogue -(Leuprolide)

Principle → Continuous administration of GnRH agonist, downregulates and desensitizes GnRH receptor of pituitary, decreasing gonadotropin release leading to decreased estrogen production. Note: In these females GnRH should be withdrawn at the age of normal puberty.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 83, 84

questions.text: All are the diaphyseal bone tumours except
questions.solution:
Diaphyseal bone tumors are tumors that occur in the shaft (diaphysis) of long bones. The other options, eosinophilic granuloma, adamantinoma, and Ewing sarcoma, can all occur in the diaphyseal region of long bones. Chondroblastoma, however, typically occurs in the epiphyseal region (the ends) of long bones rather than in the diaphysis.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 588

questions.text: A 23 years girl came to OPD with genital warts. Which is most commonly implicated in genital (vulval) warts?
questions.solution:
Genital warts are most commonly caused by HPV (Human Papillomavirus) type 6. They can have various appearances, from flat papules to classic verrucous lesions. Treatment options include removal through excision, cryotherapy, laser ablation, or cavitational ultrasonic surgical aspiration. Intralesional injection of interferon is not recommended as a primary modality due to high cost, pain, and inconvenience. The choice of treatment should be based on clinical circumstances and patient preferences.

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 1st edition, Page no 67

questions.text: All are the indications for amputation as deadly limb except
questions.solution:
'DEADLY LIMB' is a pneumonic used to remember the indications for amputation:

D - Dry gangrene

E - Extensive infection (spreading cellulitis)

A - Arterial insufficiency (inadequate blood supply)

D - Diabetes (neuropathy)

L - Lymphedema (severe)

Y - Young (severe trauma)

Paralysis is not typically an indication for amputation. The other options, wet gangrene, spreading cellulitis, and arteriovenous fistula, are all conditions that can lead to severe tissue damage or compromised blood supply, which may require amputation to prevent further complications and save the patient's life.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1014

questions.text: A 62 years old male patient had some valvular disease of the heart. His main cardinal complaint is Exertional dyspnoea, angina pectoris, and syncope. From only symptoms what is the most likely diagnosis of his valvular disease?
questions.solution:
Most patients with pure or predominant AS have gradually increasing obstruction over years but do not become symptomatic until the sixth to eighth decades.

Exertional dyspnoea, angina pectoris, and syncope are the three cardinal symptoms. Often, there is a history of insidious progression of fatigue and dyspnoea associated with gradual curtailment of activities and reduced effort tolerance.

Dyspnoea results primarily from elevation of the pulmonary capillary pressure caused by elevations of LV diastolic pressures secondary to impaired relaxation and reduced LV compliance.

Angina pectoris usually develops somewhat later and reflects an imbalance between the increased myocardial oxygen requirements and reduced oxygen availability.

Exertional syncope may result from a decline in arterial pressure caused by vasodilation in exercising muscles and inadequate vasoconstriction in non-exercising muscles in the face of a fixed CO, or from a sudden fall in CO produced by an arrhythmia.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1981

questions.text: M/C cause of PPH is:
questions.solution:
Atonicity of the uterus is the commonest cause of postpartum haemorrhage (seen in 80% cases).

With the separation of the placenta, the uterine sinuses, which are torn, cannot be compressed effectively due to imperfect contraction and retraction of the uterine musculature and bleeding continues

Reference: D C Dutta's textbook of obstetrics, 8th edition, chapter 28, page number 102

questions.text: All are the risk factors for difficult cholecystectomy except
questions.solution:
Risk factors for difficult cholecystectomy include:

B) Age > 65 years: Older patients may have more adhesions and anatomical variations, making the surgery more challenging.

C) Morbid obesity: Obese patients may have a larger and more difficult-to-access gallbladder due to increased adipose tissue.

D) High ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists) score: A high ASA score indicates that the patient has significant comorbidities, which can increase the complexity and risk of the surgery.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1249

choices.text: Start antithyroid drugs, and do urgent MRI brain
Start antithyroid drug and wait for symptoms to resolves

questions.text: A 30 years old lady with tremor and diarrhoea with elevated T4 and TSH levels were 8.5mIU/L. Further examination reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Next step of management:
questions.solution:
The clinical setting of high TSH with tremors and diarrhoea signifies hyperthyroidism due to either a TSH secreting pituitary tumor (secondary hyperthyroidism) or elevated TRH secretion from hypothalamus (tertiary hyperthyroidism).

The presence of the catch in the MCQ 'Bitemporal hemianopia' localise the lesion to Pituitary mass compressing the optic chiasma.

Hence, the diagnosis is most likely TSH secreting Pituitary adenoma.

A combination of transsphenoidal surgery, sella irradiation, and octreotide may be required to normalize TSH, because many of these tumors are large and locally invasive at the time of diagnosis.

Radioiodine or antithyroid drugs can be used to control thyrotoxicosis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2938

questions.text: A young lady presents to your office with complaints of copious vaginal discharge, but there is no cervical discharge on per speculum examination. Which of the following should be given for the management?
questions.solution:
Syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections (WHO 1991)

Principle: Treatment of STDs should be initiated at the patient's first visit to a clinic. At the same time the couple is counselled about the importance of condom use and prevention of STD transmission.

Syndromic managements are based on epidemiological studies all over the world. Syndromic diagnosis and laboratory assisted diagnosis have been found similar in terms of accuracy.

Method: Management is done by criteria for syndromic diagnosis of PID. These include detection of vaginal discharge abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, bilateral adnexal, providers are trained up to follow a standardized protocol (flow chart) to treat such a patient. This is particularly suitable in a health care setting of developing countries.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th Edition, Page no 163,164

questions.text: A 40 years old male patient is suffering from type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs should not be used in such patients?
questions.solution:
Lisinopril and Perindopril are both ACE inhibitor drugs used in hypertension. It reduces proteinuria and prevent both macro and microvascular complication,

Losartan is Angiotensin receptor blocker that has the same action on proteinuria and HTN as ACE inhibitor.

Hydrochlorothiazide is not used as an Anti-HTN drug in diabetic patient. Because thiazide diuretic causes hyperglycemia.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2083

choices.text: All hernias must be required surgical repair
Large hernias can be more dangerous than small
Pain, tenderness, skin changes and difficulty reducing imply high risk of strangulation
Femoral hernia should not always be repaired

questions.text: All are false about the management of hernia except:
questions.solution:
Surgical repair is not always required for all hernias. Some small hernias may be managed conservatively if they are asymptomatic and not causing complications. Large hernias are more dangerous than small ones. They have a higher risk of complications like incarceration and strangulation, which may require urgent surgical repair. Pain, tenderness, skin changes, and difficulty reducing may indicate hernia incarceration or strangulation, requiring urgent surgical evaluation and intervention. Femoral hernia should be repaired because they have a high risk of incarceration and strangulation. Surgical repair is typically recommended for femoral hernias.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1062

questions.text: Which of the following is rarely associated with an increased risk of developing a sarcoma?
questions.solution:
• Sarcomas are rare (<1% of all malignancies) mesenchymal neoplasms that arise in bone and soft tissues.
  • Trauma or previous injury is rarely involved, but sarcomas can arise in scar tissue resulting from a prior operation, burn, fracture, or foreign body implantation.
  • Chemical carcinogens such as polycyclic hydrocarbons, asbestos, and dioxin may be involved in the pathogenesis.
  • Kaposi sarcoma (KS) in patients with HIV type 1, classic KS, and KS in HIV-negative homosexual men is caused by human herpes virus (HHV)-8. No other sarcomas are associated with viruses.
  • Sarcomas in bone or soft tissues occur in patients who are treated with radiation therapy. The tumor nearly always arises in the irradiated field.
  • The risk increases with time. LiFraumeni syndrome is a familial cancer syndrome in which affected individuals have germline abnormalities of the tumor-suppressor gene p53 and an increased incidence of soft tissue sarcomas and other malignancies, including breast cancer, osteosarcoma, brain tumor, leukemia, and adrenal carcinoma.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 714

questions.text: A 45 years old female patient has neuroglycopenic symptoms after fasting, patient's glucose level was 2.8 mmol / L. All these symptoms were relieved by administration of glucose. These symptoms are known as:
questions.solution:
The symptoms described in the case are known as Whipple's triad, which includes symptoms induced by fasting, hypoglycaemia at the time of symptoms, and relief of symptoms with the administration of glucose. The key diagnostic test is a 72-hour fast looking for documented endogenous hyperinsulinism. If the test is positive, further imaging and tests are performed to identify the cause, such as insulinoma or other pancreatic disorders. MEN 1 should be considered in younger patients and those with multiple lesions. Chromogranin A is not a useful test for this tumor.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 906

choices.text: Patient may continue breastfeeding at her own risk
Patient should breast feed her baby only if her INR is at <2.5
Patient can breast feed her baby after 6 weeks course of warfarin is over
Warfarin is not a contraindication for lactation

questions.text: Sarita, a 30 years old woman develops a deep vein thrombosis in her left calf on fourth postoperative day following cesarean section done for foetal distress. The patient is started on heparin and is scheduled to begin a 6 weeks course of warfarin therapy. The patient is a devoted mother who wants to breastfeed her baby. What is the advice which is given to the patient?
questions.solution:
Warfarin is contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy as it can lead to contradiction syndrome comprising of microcephaly, optic atrophy, nasal hypoplasia and chondrodysplasia punctate. It can also lead to IUGR, abortions and IUD. But warfarin is absolutely safe during lactation as an extremely minute quantity of it is excreted in breast milk.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition, Page no 146

questions.text: Non healing ulcer for more than how many days is the symptom of oral cavity neoplasm.
questions.solution:
Non-healing ulcer for more than 2 weeks is a concerning symptom of an oral cavity neoplasm (cancer). Oral cavity neoplasms include tumors that can occur in the lips, tongue, buccal mucosa, floor of the mouth, palate, and other structures within the oral cavity. Any ulcer or sore in the oral cavity that persists for more than 2 weeks should be evaluated by a healthcare professional to rule out the possibility of a neoplasm or other serious conditions. Early detection and diagnosis are essential for better treatment outcomes in oral cavity cancers.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 818

questions.text: Which trinucleotide repeat disorder is the most common cause of intellectual disability?
questions.solution:
• Trinucleotide expansion was first recognized as a cause of the fragile X syndrome, one of the most common causes of intellectual disability.
  • Other disorders arising from a similar mechanism include Huntington's disease, X-linked spinobulbar muscular atrophy, and myotonic dystrophy.

Reference: Harrison's Principles Of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, page no 3648
